name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 6 July 2017.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Honorable Members, at the opening of this new session, we are forced once again to remember innocent victims of the murderous rampage of international terrorism. On behalf of all of us, I condemn with the utmost firmness these acts of inhuman violence and express our closeness and solidarity with the families of the victims of the attacks in Barcelona, ​​Cambrils and Turku. Unfortunately, other attacks have also taken place outside the borders of the European Union and we are also close to the non-European countries which are subject to this barbarism. Today, 11 September, is the sixteenth anniversary of the attacks on the Twin Towers. In recent years, many countries have been victims of repeated attacks: yet, each of them strengthens our determination to fight terrorism together and consolidates our unity and strengthens our stubborn hope for a better world. We are proud and proud of our life, of our freedom and proud of our democracy, which we will defend without changing our way of life. We do not intend to bow our heads in the face of terrorism at all. But, unfortunately, today we must also commemorate other innocent victims who lost their lives in the last tragic natural events that hit regions of the European Union, Caribbean Sea countries and even the United States this summer, until yesterday of America. In memory of all these innocent victims, I invite you to join me in a minute of silence. (The Assembly, standing, observes a minute of silence)

name: Nicola DANTI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last night the same amount of water fell in the city of Livorno in a few hours as in the last eight months. Unfortunately, this resulted in six victims, including an entire family, and two are still missing. I would like, Mr President - you have already done so with this minute of silence, where you remembered all the victims, as well as of terrorism, also of natural disasters - that the sign of closeness, solidarity and condolences of the European Parliament would arrive, of all European citizens, to the city of Livorno, so hard hit by the material difficulties that exist at the moment, and I would like it to come through a renewed commitment of this Parliament against climate change, in favor of new environmental policies, to make so that these sad events, which characterized my region yesterday, but which characterize Europe and also other parts of the world, will not be repeated. I would like this attestation of solidarity to come with a renewed commitment against climate change.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Danti, I agree with your words and it seems to me that the commitment of the European Parliament and of the entire European Union in the fight against climate change is very clear and, unfortunately, the events that are happening in Europe and outside Europe are pushing usto reinforce our commitment.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I share your words, Mr President.You spoke about the tragedies of the last few hours and recalled the dramatic terrorist attack on the Twin Towers.I would like to remind you that 44 years ago, on 11 September, a great democratic and socialist leader was bombed in the "Casa Rosada" in Santiago de Chile: Salvador Allende.I was 14 when I heard this news on the radio.His words remained and remain etched in my mind: "You can kill me but you will never kill my ideals and my values".May the words of Salvador Allende be a warning, so that we can all together fight every attack on democracy, freedom, the dignity of people.This is why we believe in the European Union;that is why we love and support a stronger Europe and stronger European integration.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Mr. President, thank you for this minute of silence with regard to all the victims of the hurricanes, in particular Irma, which affected the Caribbean and the European territories of Saint-Martin and Saint-Barthélemy. But I would also like to add to this all our wishes for courage, which must accompany the relief and security forces, so that the loss of life does not increase and that order is quickly restored. I would also like to take advantage of this intervention to salute the mobilization of the European Union, and in particular the work of the DG ECHO team, under the leadership of Commissioner Stylianides, both in Brussels, at the emergency response center, than on the ground. These efforts must be intensified. This is why I solemnly call today for the rapid mobilization of the European Solidarity Fund to envisage, as of now, a strategy of repair and reconstruction in these territories. This major crisis shows that it is a priority to increase coordination and reflection at European level to define scenarios linked to new types of risks and to consider crisis management strategies more suited to the scale of disasters to which citizens may. be confronted, in particular by promoting our know-how and our civil protection and security infrastructures that exist in Europe.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr Proust. As you well know, it is up to the States to send a report and submit a request for activation of the Solidarity Fund. Therefore, I believe that the French Republic will ask the European Commission to intervene. We, in this session, will also vote on the disbursement of EUR 1 200 000 000 for the earthquake that hit central Italy. Therefore, it seems to me that, as regards the Solidarity Fund, there has always been a rapid response from the Commission, and I believe that also on this occasion there will be a rapid reaction, which allows to send a message of concrete solidarity to the citizens French, even those overseas, who have been hit by the latest cataclysms. Parliament, as in the case of Italy, will do its duty and will vote, as soon as possible, all the proposals of the Commission regarding the disbursement of the Solidarity Fund, if the requirements are met, for the countries affected by cataclysm.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: – Mr President, I will make two very brief points. Firstly, today I read a report issued by EU citizens in the United Kingdom, highlighting the discrimination that they are now beginning to face in a variety of forms. This has been taken up by the British Government Minister. May I ask you, through your office, to provide the necessary assistance that the British Government may need in order to make sure that this matter is stamped out immediately and that such discrimination cannot be tolerated? Certainly it reminded me of a bygone era when adverts would be placed stating ‘no blacks and no dogs’. We will not tolerate any such discrimination. Secondly, what powers do you have in your office, Mr President, in terms of the award of a Sakharov Prize, when the holder of such a prize is then blatantly conducting activities, speaking words and carrying out actions which go against the very spirit on which such awards are given? How can we revisit the awards that have previously been given in such circumstances?

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: It is difficult to intervene on decisions already made;we will evaluate whether the behavior of any Sakharov Prize winner goes in the opposite direction to the spirit of the prize itself.I await, however, more information from him.Then he will have an answer.It seems difficult to me to be able to intervene ex post on what is happening.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, I wanted to echo Mr Proust’s words. His words were understandably with regard to the tragedy that has befallen the French Territories across the Caribbean, but I would also like to remind colleagues that, of course, there are British Overseas Territories also disastrously affected by this terrible hurricane Irma, and also many independent sovereign countries, so please can we get to the mindset of support for all the Caribbean nations, irrespective of whether they are French, British or independent sovereign territories. Many people across that region have been affected very badly, so let’s make this as unpolitical as we possibly can.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: As far as I am concerned, there is no difference on belonging… We observed a minute of silence to remember all the victims, in all places in Europe and outside Europe, who were caused by climatic events, in addition to terrorist ones.So of course there is no distinction between victim and victim.Then, as regards the Solidarity Fund, it will be up to the individual Member States to take the appropriate decisions.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: - Mr. President, I know that you have remembered all the victims and that, as you have rightly said, there are no differences between them, but I believe that we must also mention the victims of the earthquake that occurred in Mexico, which already addsmore than a hundred victims.They are partners and friends, a brother country of the European Union and, therefore, of this Parliament.And, therefore, I believe that it is important to give support to Mexicans and their Government at this time.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: As chairman of the delegation for relations with Mexico, you were right to remember this.But the minute of silence I dedicated to the victims also included the victims of the earthquake in Mexico, having mentioned all the cataclysms that hit the world in this terrible summer.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: In the course of its meeting on 12 July, the Legal Affairs Committee proceeded, in accordance with the regulations, to examine the compatibility with the Act of 20 September 1976 of the temporary mission entrusted by the French Prime Minister to Hon.Arnaud Danjean, who was concerned with starting the elaboration of a strategic review of defense and national security and decided that this mission is compatible with the Act.The Committee on Legal Affairs also informed me that, due to the election of the Hon.Marie Le Pen to the French National Assembly, the request for waiver of immunity presented against her no longer has reason to exist.The procedure was therefore suspended.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Mr President, on this subject, I think that this "irrelevant" is inadequate because the remarks which have been criticized against Mrs Le Pen were made in the exercise of her functions, more or less, or, in all case, when she exercised the function of MEP. However, parliamentary immunity is not intended to protect the Member. It is intended to protect the institution, our institution. Consequently, I personally consider, having sat for a very long time on the so-called Committee on Rules of Procedure, the Verification of Credentials and Immunities, when it existed, that the fact that Ms. Le Pen was subsequently elected to the French Parliament does not not exempt our institution, if it wishes - and it should do so -, from protecting the immunity of one - in this case, one - of its members, who was a Member of the European Parliament in office when they were committed the acts for which it is wrongly accused.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I limited myself to communicating a decision by the Legal Affairs Committee: today Mr Le Pen is covered by the immunity of the French system.If you have any objections, you can write a letter, legally motivating your disagreement, which we will forward to the Legal Affairs Committee for consideration.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, violence against women and domestic violence is a scourge that rages across Europe and urgent action is needed. One in three women has experienced at least one form of physical and sexual violence since the age of 15. One in twenty women has been raped. A woman dies every three days in France, following domestic violence. Behind these numbers are dramas and tragedies that have shattered the lives of many women and their children. Let me tell you a true story. A 35-year-old woman, supported by the SOS Femmes association in her department for several years, lodged a complaint against her companion for death threats in November 2015. The complaint was dismissed. Then, when she had started divorce proceedings, she was killed in November 2016 by her partner, who stabbed her with 24 stab wounds. Their 11-year-old eldest, who was present at the murder, tried to intervene to protect his mother and was injured. This is one of the realities of gender-based violence and, when this violence threatens half of our population, we must take all our responsibilities. This is what the European Union is doing by joining the Istanbul Convention. This is a strong commitment to protect women wherever they live in Europe. The Istanbul Convention is the first legally binding international instrument on violence against women. The convention pursues a comprehensive approach that combines prevention of violence, protection of victims and prosecution of those responsible. To eradicate violence against women, it is not only a question of combating the violence itself, but also a profound change in the mentalities of our society. This violence is rooted in a broader framework of discrimination and persistent inequalities between men and women. Even today, women are still confronted with sexism in the private and professional sphere, are more affected by precariousness and earn less than men, are less represented in political bodies and in corporate executives, and in the media or advertisements continue to convey stereotypes and degrading images. It is these deep roots, deeply rooted in our societies, that we must fight. There is no fatalism on my part in these remarks, but putting words into this violence and discrimination and realizing the extent of the phenomenon is an essential first step. We can act. I am thinking of education, the main driver of change in a society. From an early age, girls and boys must be educated in gender equality and respect for the dignity and fundamental rights of each person. Only education can sustainably instill new and fairer behaviors. I would like to add that this report makes it clear that denying a safe and legal abortion is violence against women, and I am not the only one to say this. The UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women recently affirmed that denial of a safe abortion is a form of gender-based violence and may even, in some cases, amount to torture. Parliament continues to speak out against the reactionary and repressive initiatives of certain governments which undermine the right to dispose of one's body. If some people think they can decide for a woman, they are wrong. We are honoring here the exemplary struggle of thousands of European women, whether Spanish, in 2014, or Polish, in 2016. I congratulate them once again for their courage and commitment. It’s a message of hope. Mobilization citizen can bend the most conservative governments and the most regressive and degrading bills. I am proud to have carried this report so important against violence against women, half of humanity, I remind you. I warmly thank the co-rapporteur, Ms Corazza Bildt, as well as all the shadow rapporteurs, who have done an admirable job on this dossier. But this is only the first step and there is still a long way to go. I will be particularly attentive to the implementation of the convention, because that is the real issue. The necessary financial and human resources are needed for these measures to have an impact on the lives of women. I therefore call on the Commission to present a comprehensive European strategy, with a legislative act on the prevention and fight against violence against women. It is urgent not to wait. All women in Europe have the absolute right to live free from violence.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, today many women and girls live in fear and despair, bleeding in body and mind, hurt and crushed by shame. Today with our report we give a voice to the millions of women whose lives are devastated by violence, saying loud and clear: You are not alone. We care. We also send a message of support to all those committed to protect women and girls – authorities, civil society – and we pay tribute to their work and tell them that the aim, with the accession of the Istanbul Convention, of the European Union is to give them more tools, a better legal framework to prevent and combat violence against women and domestic violence, and protect victims. Violence against women is a terrible crime and should be punished as such. In Europe today, at home, women continue to be beaten, and often in front of their children. In public places women risk being harassed and raped going to a swimming pool, a music festival, a beach, and more and more young women are harassed and persecuted on the net. On social media it has become a global phenomenon. I think about Tiziana, a young woman who committed suicide because of spreading her intimate videos by her ex-boyfriend, and Maria Rashidi, disfigured with acid by her husband, who, like Lucia, had the courage to denounce him and became a women’s rights activists. Many teenagers are raped: too drunk to defend themselves, with friends taking videos and publishing them on social media, thinking it is funny. It is new forms of violence – revenge pornography, sex extortion, voyeurism. Violence is now trivialised and victims are mocked. Freedom from violence, dear colleagues, is a fundamental right, and the Istanbul Convention is the first and only international legally-binding act that criminalises violence against women and recognises gender-based violence as a breach of human rights and a form of discrimination. Let us be clear: we are talking about men’s violence against women out of jealousy, revenge, frustration, alcohol. Often they cannot accept women to be strong, independent, modern, making their own choices and daring to live them. Often the culture clash for families coming from other countries and young women who just want to live like their schoolmates, in a dress, in a western way of living is too strong for their own families to accept. Is there really any honour in killing a girl just because she has decided to take off her scarf? It happened in Sweden two weeks ago. She thought she was in Europe and she could be free. Violence against women is too often tolerated and seen as a private issue, and we need to ensure more convictions of perpetrators. The Convention provides for strict sanctions to combat impunity and extend measures to protect victims, such as restraining orders, shelters, medical and psychological assistance, prevention measures, training of officials, education programmes, responsible media and combating stereotypes. It recognises that, in order to eradicate violence against women, we need to improve equality between women and men, change mentality, combat sexism, and empower women. It is time to shift the guilt from the victim to the perpetrator. Women must feel that it is not worth going through the painful process of telling the terrible stories, the shame, the embarrassment unless there is a credible judicial follow-up. Member States have to criminalise by law gender-based violence and also ensure that perpetrators are brought to justice. I visited shelters in Sweden, Italy, Malta, Greece, and many dedicated people who help women victims. More resources have to be given to them. I would like to finish by saying that I welcome the historical step forward of the EU’s signing of the Istanbul Convention in May this year. Now all the Member States need to ratify it and implement it, and we have to continue to join forces also in this Parliament.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am honoured to speak, once again, to you about gender-based violence. Your interim report is forceful and ambitious and thus reflects the urgency to take more and concrete actions against this tragedy, affecting millions of women and girls individually and society as a whole, all over Europe. I am grateful to both rapporteurs, Madam Anna Maria Corazza Bildt and Madam Christine Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy, for the huge and joint effort made in preparing the document, informed by a number of hearings that allowed gaining better insights into the phenomenon and the many challenges, both legal and practical, in combating it. I would also want to extend my thanks to the Members of the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) for the valuable input that the process received through the opinion adopted by this Committee. The Commission welcomes very much the report’s strong recognition of the Istanbul Convention as the best available to step up, together with the Member States, the European Union’s efforts in tune with our existing policy and legal framework and the Union’s international human rights agenda. Firmly rooted in international human rights instruments on gender equality, the Istanbul Convention is, on the one hand, the most comprehensive and holistic convention for the time being, and on the other hand, a highly pragmatic instrument. It requires precise actions to be taken and parties to be accounted for. Therefore, I am glad that the EU signed the Istanbul Convention in June as part of the Commission’s efforts in this year of focused actions to eliminate violence against women. The Commission will continue to push the progress towards the EU ratification in the ongoing Council discussions on the terms of conclusion. Still, let me recall the mixed character of the Convention, which includes areas that are not covered by Union exclusive competence. This will continue to raise difficult and sometimes sensitive questions that we will need to reconcile with the political ambitions that are widely shared with the vast majority of Member States. Beyond the strong support for the Union’s accession expressed in the report, we are also grateful for the many concrete indications on how to arrange the EU’s future implementation of the Convention’s obligations, both in organisational and substantive terms. We will give them thorough consideration. The report rightly emphasises the need to give particular attention to vulnerable groups to address their specific needs, such as female refugees, and to enable all victims to actually use support facilities, as well as the links between violence and economic dependence and empowerment and the related need to see our efforts to combat violence as part of our overall strategy to achieve full and genuine gender equality in the European Union. I would like to use this opportunity to inform you that this year, the annual European Commission colloquium on fundamental rights, led by first Vice-President Timmermans and myself, will be dedicated to women’s rights, and that violence against women is one of the key topics on its agenda. It will take place on 20 and 21 November. I am pleased that the parliamentary event on violence against women will also take place on 21 November. These initiatives from the Commission and the Parliament will bring the issue of violence to the forefront of the political agenda in the EU: a place where it deserves to be.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Rapporteur of the Committee on Legal Affairs. - Madam President, sad data and surveys show that one in three women in Europe will experience physical or sexual violence in their adult lives. One in five women in Europe then encountered online harassment or dangerous stalking. The European Union's annual cost of violence against women and gender-based violence is estimated at two hundred and twenty-eight billion euros. In the Czech Republic, where I come from, it is estimated that up to 6,000 cases of rape take place every year, with only about a tenth of victims seeking help. These are alarming numbers. The Istanbul Convention, which we are talking about here today, enshrines, above all, the duty of prevention, the principle of protection and support for victims, as well as the prosecution of perpetrators of violence and domestic violence. In the Committee on Legal Affairs, we have unequivocally supported the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention. We believe that we need an effective and enforceable instrument at European level to eradicate domestic violence.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to congratulate the current Maltese Presidency, who pushed hard to get the convention signed, and to thank my fellow rapporteurs for their excellent work. Although this is an interim report, it is important for the European Parliament to reaffirm its firm and firm stance against violence against women. Violence against women is an endemic, deep-rooted social scourge that knows no borders, in Europe as in any other part of the world: women suffer daily abuse and violence, with devastating physical and psychological consequences. Statistics need to be updated every hour, every minute, every second. The European Union has made gender equality one of its founding principles but often women in every sector have to do much more than men to ensure their rights are protected and are, at the same time, strongly discriminated against in participating in economic life , social, political and cultural, as well as being under-represented in the various decision-making processes. If violence is added to these unfavorable conditions, the principle of equality loses all meaning. Dear colleagues, these reasons have guided my work in the eight years that have seen me as a Member of the European Parliament: I have participated in countless initiatives to ask for the accession of the European Union to the Council of Europe convention on preventing and combating violence against women. The convention, through its comprehensive legal framework to prevent, prosecute and eliminate violence, will send a strong political message on the Union's commitment to combat this phenomenon. But since the European Union cannot claim the primacy of its right in this field, the repression of these discriminatory and violent phenomena, based precisely on gender, has so far been competence of the various internal rights, with inevitable repercussions on the level of differences, not only in terms of sanctioning responses to those who commit these crimes, but also in terms of support for women themselves.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I know there is unfortunately a great deal to be said in these areas.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, for a long time we have been demanding the need to consider gender violence as a problem of public order, as a responsibility shared by the whole of society, and not a problem that must be solved in the sphere of the family or in the sphere of of the houses. We believe that it is therefore important - and for this we welcome ourselves - to have this debate today on the ratification of the Istanbul Convention. Because the Istanbul Convention is the legal instrument with the greatest impact at this time to be able to act on gender violence. We are talking about a social scourge, we are talking about women who are being murdered at the hands of men for the mere fact of living in unequal societies, for the mere fact of being women. And we are talking about the shared responsibility of all the institutions, including the European institutions, to put an end to this reality. The commissioner has also made reference to the most vulnerable groups. And, in this sense, we wanted to make a specific reference to the situation of a vulnerable group, such as minors from families where gender-based violence has been suffered. I announce here today that our Group will present for the next debate with the European Commission - and we hope that with the support of other parliamentary groups - a debate on this issue, on the protection of the rights of minors who have also been victims of violence. gender in families. Because there is the possibility of resorting to enhanced cooperation, as the European Union has done with the Lisbon Regulation or with the Rome Regulation in this regard. And it is necessary to talk about the rights of minors; It is necessary to talk about the protection of minors, because they are the most vulnerable victims. We cannot allow any more complicit silences against gender violence, because we speak of half the population. We talk about women, who have to claim to be in equality of conditions with the rest of society.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Violence against women and gender-based violence continues to be grossly underestimated and minimized. Violence against women, but we cannot accept violence against men and children as well, is unacceptable. According to the recent study by the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, one in five women in the EU has experienced physical violence by someone other than their partner since the age of 15. And women with a disability are estimated to have an estimated 1.5 to 10 times more risk of abuse. Distressing figures. The EU must of course accede to the Istanbul Convention. We must end violence against women and girls in every possible way. Only 14 EU countries, including Belgium, have ratified the Istanbul Convention so far. Of course, the Member States must also do their part. But the EU can work in addition to this, for example in connection with the rights of victims and in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters. It is high time that we make the fight against gender-based violence an absolute priority.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President! As a defender of human rights and women's rights, I of course welcome the European Union's accession to the Istanbul Convention. This is an effective instrument to further strengthen the pioneering role of the European Union in the fight against violence against women. The binding legal act is an important addition to the existing treaties, norms and standards in the field of women's rights worldwide and should be seen as the golden standard. For this reason I also regret the Council's decision not to accede to the convention to the greatest possible extent, but to restrict itself to just a few chapters. Our declared goal must be for EU accession to the Istanbul Convention to make a noticeable difference in the fight against violence against women. For this it would be necessary to choose the most ambitious and not the easiest way. My experience as a politician has shown that we can never take rights - especially women's rights - for granted. We must fight consistently and tirelessly for these rights and raise our voices until, hopefully, at some point a generation of young Europeans will see violence against women as completely intolerable - an offense for which there can never be any justification.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, every minute we silence a woman becomes a victim: a victim of psychological, sexual, verbal, gender, domestic violence. The Istanbul Convention can break the deafening silence. How; Putting an end to impunity, protecting victims, preventing various forms of violence. Colleagues, is the ratification of the contract enough as we obviously ask? Of course not. It needs to be implemented quickly and innovative measures adopted. I propose the creation of a pan-European hotline for victims of gender and domestic violence, similar to hotline 112. I call on the Commissioner to consider the proposal. We must not forget that society prepares crime and the criminal commits it. Victor Hugo also said that to the "Miserables". So if we want a society and a culture of peace, no one should be a victim, no one should be the perpetrator but, above all, no one should remain an observer.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, a month ago I was walking home from a night out with friends. As I was approaching Duisburg main station, a guy came up to me very suddenly from behind, without me seeing him, and grabbed me between my legs. I turned around – I was in complete shock and was outraged – and tried to run after him and scream and curse at him with only one thought in my head: that if I scared him enough, he would not do this to any other woman again in his life. After a couple of blocks, I lost him in the dark and I called the police. The police came straight away with three cars. They interrogated me and asked me if I was feeling fine, and whether I needed psychological support. They called for a search to find this guy and even took my jacket and my dress to find traces. I felt safe again. They brought me home and I felt that I was taken seriously at this time. I know that I owe this police reaction to the debates that we had in the last month around the Istanbul Convention. That is why I now want to give my thanks to all the women in this Chamber, and also in the Member States and all over the world, who have fought for this to happen. But still, even though I had this positive experience, there are tens of thousands of women who do not get this treatment when they are harassed or face sexualised violence. They still face being ridiculed and not being taken seriously. Without the millions of women who fought for this Convention and for other steps that were taken against violence against women, this would not have been possible. So without these pioneers and without documents like the Istanbul Convention, the fight against violence against women is still not a given. The fact that I could feel safe and that we are struggling to have every single woman in the world feeling safe needs to be our motivation to continue and to exceed the Istanbul Convention in its full scope and not to let one day pass without fighting against violence against women. So we need to take this step now. This will certainly not be the last step, but a very important and historic step on the way to a society without violence against women. (Applause)

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, violence against women, and indeed all kinds of violence against any gender is something that all sides of the political spectrum can unanimously condemn. The UK has for many years played a leading role in protecting women, and this has statistically led to a decrease in domestic violence cases. Despite this improvement, it is reported that in 2016 alone there were at least 1.3 million female victims of domestic abuse in the United Kingdom. This is quite simply unacceptable in the 21st century and more must be done to tackle this worrying statistic. Many Member States in this Union, including the United Kingdom, are working towards making the necessary legislative changes to meet the criteria of the Istanbul Convention to allow full ratification. The EU accession to this Convention therefore serves to provide the political leverage for the EU to further control the implementation of this Convention in Member States. National legislation, tougher judicial punishments and a greater emphasis on educating citizens is the best way to significantly combat violence against women across Europe.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, the European Union’s proposal for accession to the Convention on the Prevention of Violence against Women, known as the Istanbul Convention, poses many legal and political problems. Violence against women, whatever its origin or form, must be fought fiercely. The woman is what we hold most dear on this earth: it is she who gives life. No civilized society can tolerate the slightest violence against these women, against women all over the world. France, like all the countries of the European Union, fights daily against all forms of violence that affect women. If our leaders sometimes lack foresight on the new threats weighing on them - I am thinking in particular of radical Islamism which locks them in from all points of view - they are the only ones who have the instruments of criminal law to fight against this violence. . The European Union is by no means legitimate to accede to the convention and even less to ratify it. Only sovereign states can and it will not have escaped your notice that only 14 out of 28 member states have. How can you not interpret your request for ratification as a new attempt to override the opinion of the people and as the establishment of a supra-state decision-making process? Indeed, once ratified by the European Union, the Istanbul Convention can be imposed on States which do not wish to ratify it. It was for show; let's get to the bottom of it. If the text of the convention and your justification for ratifying it were good, we could have rethought the way to proceed and focused on the root of the problem: violence against women. Why do some Member States rightly refuse to ratify a convention aimed at combating violence against women? Certainly because they are aware of your faults communitarianism and the ideological aspect of this convention. Once the convention has been ratified and finally imposed on all member states, any criticism of - I quote - sex, gender, race, color, language, religion, fortune, birth, sexual orientation, gender identity, age, migrant or refugee, political opinion, opinion simply and national or social origin will be condemned. Your text is not intended to concretely protect women victims of violence. It aims above all to establish communitarianism. The only thing these communities have in common is that they will be oppressed by the culprit of all evil: the white male, straight, racist, homophobic, xenophobic, transphobic and so on. Ladies rapporteurs, because at no point in your text you mention it, I would like to end by emphasizing the danger that weighs today on European women threatened in their body and soul by hordes of uncontrollable migrants . Unfortunately, the news regularly gives us sordid examples and this danger owes its existence only to the suicidal migration policy that you support. Your narrow and stunted view of women is an insult to the genius of which they are capable. Sainte Geneviève, Joan of Arc and Marie Curie, thank God, did not need your assistantship policies, nor your quotas to show all their value and all their courage.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Madam President, I acknowledge through my work that this is a violation of human rights and that it is necessary to have measures to protect victims as well as to prevent, prosecute, combat and eliminate them. However, the over-promotion of specific ideological views with ambiguous types of humanitarian formulations reinforces stereotypes and disorients citizens. The establishment of independent expert committees and teams with the mandatory support of NGOs that institute dangerous exceptions to the deportation of illegal immigrants or criminalize everyday life through abstract notions of moral harassment will complicate national legal frameworks for the respective penal codes. If the aim is indeed to reduce violence and not cynology, I propose that the binding obligations to women victims of domestic violence be extended to all men and that the Commission be limited to ensuring practical international co-operation. All forms of physical and sexual violence, as well as related crimes, require very severe criminal treatment, under the full jurisdiction of the Member States.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Thank you, Vice-President, Commissioner, many people are aware of my commitment to combating violence against women and children. However, I received thousands of e-mails in the e-mail from citizens from Slovakia who do not agree with the EU joining the Istanbul Convention. Allow me a brief quote from these e-mails: “The fight against violence against women, the assistance to its victims, as well as education as part of the prevention of violence are among the exclusive competences of the EU Member States. By joining the so-called The European Union would violate the Treaty of Lisbon and exceed its powers. ”You also received the full text of the letter, which is addressed to you by thousands of Europeans. However, you will find it hidden in the spam folder. And I consider this outrageous. The European Parliament simply cannot adopt rules that automatically hide a request signed by thousands of EU citizens and then silently delete it. Each Member must be able to decide for himself how to deal with correspondence from his constituents. That is why I am asking President Tajani to ensure, before the vote, that all these e-mails are transferred to the so-called Inbox. Otherwise, it will be difficult to explain that this Parliament really cares about the views of the citizens of the European Union that it is supposed to represent.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President! In recent years we have also seen a very unfortunate trend in Europe: violence, especially physical violence, is being trivialized more and more. This also and especially applies to women. That's shocking. It happens everywhere, in all walks of life, in all age groups and in all Member States. Yes, and it has become socially acceptable again to make fun of women in a sexist way. It is well known that everything begins with words. The Istanbul Convention is an attempt by the international community to put a stop to these tendencies: It clearly states that violence against women and domestic violence represent a violation of human rights and should be prosecuted accordingly. The European Parliament has campaigned for this in all phases and has always worked to ensure that we are ready today. It would probably have taken longer without our involvement. And one can rightly complain that everything takes so terribly long. But it is important that it doesn't stop at Sunday speeches. And it's primarily about implementation, it's about ensuring that existing law is actually implemented. The resolution of the LIBE and FEMM committees points in the right direction. It shows how to proceed. It is particularly important that appropriate education and awareness measures are taken. Surely it cannot be that young people experience violence as “cool”. The aim is to raise awareness among the state bodies such as the police and the judiciary. There must be a clear awareness here, otherwise everything will be just paper and wishful thinking, and that shouldn't be. (The speaker declined to answer a question from Mr Jurek about the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, violence against women and domestic violence are inexcusable acts that achieve nothing other than undue suffering, misery and inequality on an unjustifiable scale. Both have existed for far too long and have claimed too many victims. Both constitute a gross violation of human rights and it cannot be clearer that action is urgently needed.  The Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding instrument on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence at the international level, opens the door to fundamental change. It provides the recognition and the tools needed to put an end to the long history of such appalling violence, which has devastating consequences for individuals, families and society. As a whole, I therefore urge all Member States that have not already done so to work towards the swiftest possible ratification of this Convention.  However, unfortunately some aspects of the interim report go way beyond the scope of the Convention and encroach upon the competences of the Member States themselves. I want to be absolutely clear that it is for this reason and this reason alone, that I do not support this report. Unfortunately, because other Members have not listened to those of us who had that reservation, I will have to abstain on this report.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Madam president; Thank you, Commissioner Jourová for your tireless work. The Istanbul Convention is a legal milestone and essential achievement in protecting women across Europe from violence. However, that only half of the Member States of the Union have ratified it ... well, I don't know what to think, or what can be done. I do not find any argument, nor do I think we can admit it. Even in the countries that have already ratified it, we cannot be satisfied. In my country, in Spain, ratification took place three years ago and yet it has not been translated into concrete measures. Although a state pact against gender violence has recently been signed between the main Spanish parties, this pact falls short compared to the Istanbul Convention. We don't need more pacts, we don't need more photos or more words. We need the Istanbul Convention to be translated into concrete measures. Only legal change truly leads to cultural change. Let us equip ourselves with the best comprehensive tool against gender violence; Moreover, against all violence, against domestic violence, which is against the most vulnerable. I am addressing the governments of all Europe: please do your job.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Madam President, violence against women, like domestic violence, has in its genesis a complex web of economic, social, political and cultural causes that cannot be ignored, that remain and that get worse in our society. These causes are associated and interconnected with psychological dynamics that lead many women to dead ends as a result of feelings of guilt, fear and shame, responsibility for maintaining the family unit at all costs, family and social pressure . The success of preventing, combating and eradicating violence against women in its multiple forms is inseparable from the realization of women's rights in law and in life, from guaranteeing equal participation, both in the private and family spheres, as well as in the labor, social, politics and sports, the alteration of ancient concepts based on the subordination of the role of women in the family, at work and in society, the promotion of a culture based on the values ​​of freedom, democracy, equality, justice and progress.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today the European Union is officially a party to the Istanbul Convention, albeit limited to the areas of judicial cooperation in criminal matters and asylum and refoulement requests. The convention, despite some ambiguities and controversies still to be defined, is certainly a useful tool to stop the great river of violence that hits European women every day. The partial accession, however, and the lack of ratification by many Member States, do not yet allow us to assess the effective effectiveness of the measures it envisages. With this act, the Union becomes aware of the serious scourge afflicting women. But this must not be the point of arrival, but the beginning of a new flourishing season of not purely theoretical acts with which to concretely combat violence against women; because despite ratification in several Member States, there is no sign of diminishing the wave of violence in them and the daily news reminds us of this. In this regard, I would like to mention the ruling of the European Court of Human Rights last March, with which Italy, one of the first Member States to sign and ratify the convention, was declared in default in protecting a victim of acts of domestic violence and therefore ordered to pay compensation. By this I mean that the mere act of ratification obviously cannot by itself stop the violence. Instead, a synergy is needed between the legislative and judicial systems, involving law enforcement and assistance services. Justice must be friendlier to women and therefore must be swift and certain. It is also necessary to implement the economic resources of all the structures in charge of assisting and helping women, also and above all in smaller centers, where it is even more difficult to report the violence suffered, especially if domestic. My wish is to lay the foundations for a future where my daughter and our daughters can walk the streets of Europe without fear of being victims of violence.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Madam President! Joining the Istanbul Convention is certainly a good thing or an interesting thing - but joining a convention alone does not, of course, solve the problems that have now pent up in Europe. Let me point out a dark segment of these problems: what was unthinkable in Europe 10 to 15 years ago is now a bitter reality in many cities in the Union. Religious violence against women in parts of society, which is shaped by Sharia law, is not only a fact, but is unfortunately increasingly not even prosecuted by our courts. Honor killings of women of the second and third generation of migrants are often carried out in full agreement and with the consent of the family and their clans. The number of unreported cases of child marriages is increasing rapidly: They are concluded abroad and mostly helplessly approved by our authorities. I wonder where our much-invoked European values ​​are. Or when I think of New Year's Eve 2015/2016 in Cologne as an example and then of numerous Austrian and German cities on New Year's Eve, where there was massive sexual assault on women, then this clearly shows this dire development: namely, the contempt for western European image of women by a growing part of the fundamental Islamic population - not least due to the mass immigration of 2015. I believe the Union is increasingly blind and inactive here and ignores these socio-religious problems. Increasing the gender budget would not help us much. The vicious circle of silence and the vicious circle of loneliness must be put to an end. Violence against women, I agree with you, of course, is not a private matter. Sexual assaults and abuses cannot be excused by referring to tradition, custom or “one has a different culture”.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: - Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT on all her intervention in this fight and all the colleagues who raised their voices. The fight against discrimination must be a cause for everyone, whether men or women, younger or older. It is a common purpose that is an integral part of what unites us as Europeans. Violence against women, in particular domestic violence, is unfortunately the cause and effect of discrimination of which many - too many! - women are still targeted. Preventing and punishing this practice, which is absolutely intolerable, must also be the goal of everyone: local communities, Member States, and the European Union itself. The Istanbul Convention is naturally an excellent instrument for this purpose. That is why I appeal to those Member States that have not yet acceded to the Convention to do so quickly, and I agree that the Union must also accede so that in the areas where it is competent it can act fully in the application of this Convention and in the fight against discrimination. Ladies and gentlemen, it is our duty to combat this suffering and create conditions for European women to live in freedom and without fear. Let us put the accessory aside and focus on what really matters. There are European women who still suffer and this must end!

name: Maria NOICHL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Dear Evelyn, I am particularly pleased that you are in the chair today, because I know that you have been campaigning for this topic for decades and have been fighting against violence against women in Europe. Thank you very much for that. I therefore say “for decades”, to refer to the previous speaker again. If he thinks that the issue of violence against women has only recently come to Europe with the issue of refugees, then in the last few decades he has probably been in a different Europe than I was. The issue of violence has been an issue in Europe for decades, regardless of refugees. I bring the impatience with me today, you can hear it in my voice. You hear the impatience in my voice that we finally have to stop, that we just keep talking about it, but that we finally have to do something to make something happen. Something has to happen so that perpetrators are named and punished, so that victims are helped, so that it is made clear that sexual violence also takes place in Christian marriages. I don't need to look at the Sharia, I just need to look at what's going on in my own bedrooms. It is important to look, it is important to change something. Commissioner, the subject is in good hands with you. Please, please, please move forward in Europe!

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the Istanbul Convention undoubtedly has some lofty goals in combating violence against women, but it also has some serious problems. Any violence, not only against women, but also against physically and mentally disadvantaged people, children, women or the elderly, is reprehensible. That is why I welcome such legislative and non-legislative instruments that help to address the form of abominable violence - every form. Especially if they are addressed in the Member States themselves, which can intervene most effectively. Unfortunately, this cannot be said of this Istanbul Convention, which contains a number of unwanted agendas that undermine the foundations of the European Union. I am all the more disappointed with the position of the European Parliament, which goes far beyond its competences and even extends the scope of the Convention. References to pofider gender ideology can be traced in the text, which inexplicably tries to portray the biological differences between a man and a woman as a social construct and other peculiar nonsense. I call on Members of Parliament to vote against. Not because of the content, but because of the very fact that it is the wrong legal instrument by which the Member States delegate part of their powers to the Council of Europe.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, thank you to the rapporteurs and Commissioner Jourová for all her work.Gender-based violence affects 250 million women in Europe and costs us 230 billion euros a year, figures that justify the adherence of community institutions to the Istanbul Protocol.This measure will help us to have a coherent legal framework in all the Member States, it will improve measures to prevent and fight this scourge, and it will help us to better protect and repair the victims of what many of us call domestic terrorism.The threats and screams that we hear on the other side of the wall are everyone's problem.The values that drive abusers are corrosive.The stereotypes that we transmit in education or in the media kill.For this reason, the fight against this scourge begins in each one of us.And that individual action needs and deserves the maximum institutional support.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: - Madam President, we certainly welcome the ratification of the Istanbul Convention and, furthermore, we urgently appeal to those Member States that have not yet ratified it to do so. This Convention recognizes violence against women as a violation of human rights and this recognition on paper is important, but today, I believe that out of respect for the victims of sexist violence, we should not and cannot make triumphant statements. We have to redouble our efforts to translate what is written on paper into action. That is why I also support the Parliament Resolution, which calls on States to allocate financial and human resources, necessary to prevent and combat violence and to protect and assist victims. We have seen it in my country these months with the case of Juana Rivas, forced to hand over her children to an abusive father, already convicted of it and pending another complaint. And the thing is that, in my country, the law against gender violence does not include the withdrawal of custody of abusive parents. No abuser is a good parent. For this reason, we must continue to go beyond this Convention, because it is an urgent need to provide ourselves with a European Directive to combat violence against women and minors, which is mandatory for all States.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Madam President, my country, the UK, is I think sliding backwards into medieval times. In my childhood the following five crimes were virtually unheard of and now they are commonplace: female genital mutilation; breast ironing; forced marriage, which is effectively legalised rape; honour violence, which includes killing; and sexual grooming of vulnerable white girls by Asian men. There is an enormous reluctance to prosecute the perpetrators of these crimes because they are either from ethnic minorities or adherents of Islam and it is considered politically incorrect to criticise such groups generically. It is called racism. Political correctness is the cornerstone of this European Union and it is doing enormous damage to the safety of women. We now have a situation where perceived racism is a more serious crime than actual rape. We have got to stop political correctness and defend women.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: All crimes must be prosecuted.That is probably clear, that is normal in legal acts.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: - Madam President, I welcome the proposal for a Council decision for the European Union to accede to the Council of Europe Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence, within the exclusive competence of the European Union. This issue is very important, it is also important that the European Union respects the principle of subsidiarity. Let me therefore express my doubts about the text of the resolution tabled. In my view, the motion for a resolution touches on matters which fall within the competence of the Member States. Citizens expect an effective European Union based on the strict application of the principle of subsidiarity. I am not convinced that, by voting in favor of the text presented, we will meet these expectations of our citizens. I regret that, by failing to respect the principles of subsidiarity, the motion for a resolution dilutes the support that the Istanbul Convention itself deserves. It is important to draw attention to violence against women, any violence is unacceptable, violence destroys society. Victims of violence never have to participate fully in society. Violence against women, like any other violence, is therefore a criminal offense under the law of each state. I have not previously supported resolutions whose text touched on matters falling within the competence of nation states, and unfortunately I will have to do the same in the case of this resolution.

name: Soraya POST
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! The prevailing gender power order is a global structure which means that men as a group are superior to women as a group. This structure is supported by norms of masculinity, where the right to exercise control is an important part. As a result, more than 90 percent of men are perpetrators of total violence in the world. That is why we need to reformulate the overall security agenda. The traditional security policy is patriarchal and is based on men with military means defending the nation, its women and children. We would rather protect a flag than the woman who is financially controlled by a man. A feminist analysis of security is based on human security, where threats to individuals and not states are central. I would have liked to have seen the report address this: a recognition that a society free from violence must have a completely different security policy agenda. Of course, I support this report by colleagues Christine and Anna Maria.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Madam President!Any violence against a woman is a pathology that must be fought against.However, let us not pretend that the Istanbul Convention is a magic wand that will free us from this problem.In essence, the Istanbul Convention is an ideological crowbar which, under the guise of supporting victims of violence, makes social relations a victim of gender ideology and radical feminism.Do MEPs voting tomorrow really want to endorse that violence against women is a permanent feature of European society?And that's the point of it.Let's face it.Ideology does not cease to be a threat just because it sometimes takes the side of a helpless victim.Joining the ideological convention will be another tragic mistake of the European Union, which is why I am calling for its rejection.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, one third of European women have experienced physical violence at least once in their adult lives. However, these statistics do not necessarily reflect reality, as they are based solely on victim reports. The real numbers can be much higher when we think of the fear of the victims or the dependence on the abusive party. When I think of the female members of my family, I can’t turn my head. Violence against women is not a private matter, as it is a serious and systematic violation of women's fundamental human rights and dignity. A crime that should be sanctioned. Equality between citizens is one of the fundamental values ​​of the Union. The Union's accession to the Istanbul Convention is therefore to be welcomed, all the more so as, although all 14 Member States have signed it, only 14 have ratified it. Violence against women in the EU costs society billions of euros a year. Emphasis should be placed not only on the fight against violence, but also on prevention, awareness-raising and information. Media and advertising play a key role in this. These platforms, in cooperation with non-governmental organizations, should play an active role in conducting information and education campaigns, as this is a precondition for achieving gender equality.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I am not going to talk about the data and the social and personal damage of gender-based violence that are well known to all of us. Other financial costs are also public, but the costs on the body and soul of these women are not quantifiable. Gender-based violence affects the 500 million citizens living in this Union. That is why the real implementation of the Istanbul Convention is essential, accompanied by other measures, namely that the austerity policies that have both promoted and promote inequality. Hence, Commissioner, it is urgent to present a proposal for a legal act to support Member States in preventing and suppressing all forms of violence against women and girls. It is about human rights and this is a competence of the European Union. But this too is not done without education. On the other hand, I feel it is unworthy to wait for the passerelle clause for this Union to move forward in the fight against gender violence. We should be much more united in this fight. Thank you.

name: Rikke-Louise KARLSSON
text: - Sir. Chairman! Dear colleagues! In my world, we all have a shared responsibility to distance ourselves from the violence and abuse that women face every single day. We should take the lead in any measure that can prevent women from being beaten, raped and, in the worst case, killed in their own homes. That is why, of course, I also support the good and strong report we have before us today. I support the fact that we are making strong and effective legislation that can put an end to violence, while the victims and the thousands of children who live in the shadow of violence every day will continue to be protected as well as possible in the future. In the EU, our unity is built on common values ​​and trust. As members of a common Europe, I believe that we must always distance ourselves from violence, no matter what form it may take. Whether it is the Member States themselves who must fight violence, it is important that we send a strong signal from here that violence is not okay, no matter where you come from or what religion you profess.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Mr President, I think it is sad somewhere that we still have to argue about the need to bring the Istanbul Convention into force. We know exactly that gender equality, women's equality, is one of the fundamental standards of democracy. Violence against women is not just a matter for women at all, there is no question that it is a private matter, but a public matter that poisons, violates and destroys democracy. It is a social problem that requires complex legal, social, health, educational and cultural measures and their implementation. That is why all Member States must ratify the Istanbul Convention without reservation. I am very sorry that it is the Hungarian Government that is unwilling to do this, and even goes in the opposite direction by trying to restrict women's reproductive rights, to create centers that discourage the Russian model, centers that discourage abortion. I think this is not allowed in any European Member State, which is why we need to ratify the Istanbul Convention.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: - Mister President! An alarmingly high number of women say they have been victims of domestic violence. In addition, with the influx of Islamic cultures in recent years, completely new forms of violence have emerged, such as the circumcision of girls, honor killings, but also multiple marriages or child marriages - all forms of violence and oppression that are actually prohibited in my country which are nevertheless often part of everyday life for women and girls in parallel societies. That this is a threat for all women in Central Europe is shown by the latest court rulings from Germany, which shockingly value the cultural character of the male perpetrator higher than the rights of women. But that a completely wrong immigration policy - especially in my country - exacerbates the problems for women even more is tragic. On my way to the airport in Hamburg today, I drove through several parts of the city, where a large majority of women in nikab and burqa are out and about and young women in miniskirts or jeans were almost invisible. For me this is a clear sign that all reprisals must be counteracted here. For these reasons, I welcome the Istanbul Agreement.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all congratulations to the two co-rapporteurs, Ms Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy and Ms Corazza Bildt, for their excellent work. Like all of you, I remain dismayed by these tragic situations that too many women and their children still experience on a daily basis. While we advocate human rights, they are still too often denied to these women victims of domestic violence. How is it that even today, we read that one in twenty women between the ages of 19 and 28 has been raped in Europe, that one in three women has been the victim of physical violence at a young age and as a young adult? It is imperative to react individually but also together in order to define a common strategy allowing equal protection of our fellow citizens on the territory of the European Union. What shocks me today is in particular the behavior of some of our very conservative colleagues from different political groups who hide behind subsidiarity to reject this text, behavior which is really conservative, guilty of not progressing towards a situation better than ratification by all member states of the Istanbul Convention.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, violence against women unfortunately continues. The numbers are merciless: a third of European women have suffered acts of physical violence, and more, at least once in their life. In this scenario, the Istanbul Convention offers useful legal instruments not only to prosecute the perpetrators, but also to prevent violence against women and the Union's accession to the convention is a strong and unified signal towards the many, too many women victims of violence. I therefore hope that all the Member States want to implement the convention effectively, as did my country, Italy, for example, where a few days ago guidelines were approved that provide for preventive educational tools, protection programs and support for victims and closer collaboration between the Ministry of Justice and the courts to punish the guilty. In all European countries, there is a need for an integrated policy against all forms of violence against women, a phenomenon with respect to which we certainly cannot turn the other way.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: - Mr. President, the whole process of ratification of the Istanbul Convention is taking too long.It’s been a year and a half, and we’re still debating.It's devastating.In the EU, seven women die from the effects of violence every day.I am particularly concerned about research showing that violence has become acceptable among school-age children.It has become normal to verbally or physically assault a girl or a girl if she does not act in accordance with the expectations of the environment.Women face discrimination and violence on a daily basis, and it is especially difficult if they are people with disabilities or if they belong to the LGBTI group.I am shocked that some even in a document like this, whose importance should be understood, look for a way to suppress gender equality or, moreover, claim that the ratification of the Istanbul Convention endangers women's rights.I support this report because it calls for a comprehensive ratification of the Convention, but above all an urgent ratification.

name: Anna HEDH
text: - Mr President! The Istanbul Convention is a milestone in the fight against men's violence against women. Its starting point is that violence is an expression of unequal power relations between women and men and states that violence against women is gender-related at a structural level. Now it is very important that all member states ratify the Istanbul Convention, take their responsibility and seriously tackle men's violence against women. Conventions that just remain beautiful words on paper do not help. The Convention must be fully implemented. A very important part of Parliament's text is that it states that the denial of sexual and reproductive health services, including safe and legal abortion, constitutes a form of violence against women and girls. What surprises me, however, is how the EPP is now trying to erode the text. In my opinion, there seemed to be a consensus on the important points of the text at committee level. I am very disappointed in you, Anna Maria Corazza Bildt, who is a supporter of the EPP that you have now allowed the EPP to break out writings about LGBTQ people, sexism and hate crimes. At home, you let something completely different shine. I wonder if the EPP really wants to fight gender-based violence.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: question ("blue card").- I want to turn to my dear colleague Anna Hedh.I belong to the EPP and wanted to run this report.It was I who asked Commissioner Jourová in her 2014 hearing to put forward proposals for the EU to have access to the Istanbul Convention.The report has not been put to the vote yet, so I do not understand how you can attack the EPP members if you do not know how to vote.It is about fighting and preventing violence against women and violence in close relationships and about protecting victims.That is what the report is about.We in the EPP agree to support the report with a zero tolerance policy.

name: Anna HEDH
text: answer ("blue card").- There are many - very many - who have demanded work from the EU against men's violence against women for several years.What I highlight is that I am disappointed to hear that the EPP now wants to highlight many important things that we have agreed on at committee level.It worries me that we're starting to break things down now that we've got a good document.That's what I'm disappointed with, ie.that the EPP is now threatening to do so.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, the European Parliament will continue to comment on the European Union's accession to the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence. Violence is a sad reality and it does not shy away from a culturally advanced society like the European one. And we should not stick our heads in the sand before this phenomenon. I support the Council's proposal, which proposes that the European Union accede to the Convention in areas which belong to the European Union, such as asylum or judicial cooperation. The European Union should assist Member States in combating violence against women in forms that can be successfully implemented in the Member States and can vary. For example, the Czech Republic has a law on protection against domestic violence from 2006, when the convention did not even exist. I agree with my colleague Corazza Bildt that the Group of the European People's Party is in favor of zero tolerance of violence against women. Ladies and gentlemen, as we vote on the amendments, I will join the draft report.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - Mr President, we have repeatedly addressed the issue of domestic violence and violence against women here. One in three women in the European Union has experienced some form of violence. It is particularly serious and reprehensible that up to 80% of women with disabilities, who have a significantly lower ability to defend themselves against an attacker, become victims of domestic physical or psychological violence. At the same time, only a small percentage of perpetrators remain punished, as victims often cannot or do not want to contact the police. That is also part of the problem. The only legally binding international instrument to prevent and combat violence against women is the Istanbul Convention. It commits states to work to prevent violence, protect its victims and prosecute perpetrators, and suggests concrete steps to do so. It is good that the Council and all the Member States of the European Union have already signed the convention. But now it is important that our determination does not end with just this signature. We have a really long way to go.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, we are discussing today the leading event of domestic violence and violence against women. In fact, on 23 November 2016, I had the opportunity to speak here in Strasbourg in the plenary session of the European Parliament on the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention. And all this at a time when the economic crisis, poverty and unemployment are a fertilizer for the development of domestic violence in Europe. At the same time, sexual harassment, rape, and genital mutilation in Sharia continue even more intensely, leading to a serious violation of human rights. I believe that the accession of the European Union to the Council of Europe Convention under discussion will make a decisive contribution to the protection of minors and women from all forms of violence and will also lead to the prosecution of perpetrators. At the same time, however, the Istanbul Convention should not be used as a mechanism for the stay and non-repatriation of illegal immigrants, as well as as a mechanism for legitimizing Islamization in Europe.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: - Mister President! I would also like to thank the Commissioner and the two rapporteurs very much. It is really very important that the Istanbul Convention is now also supported by the EU. All member states should not only sign but also ratify. That has already been said. And what has been said is also correct again, that the signature and ratification alone does not remove violence against women from the world. But we have to do something in all areas. It was also said that in Europe this supposedly only played a role since we got the refugees. That's completely wrong, it always has been. But because of the refugees we have a special group of particularly vulnerable women, namely the refugee women. So I think it's very good that the Maltese Presidency has already taken care of violence prevention and pregnancy. In Germany we have a violence prevention project for refugee women and children and migrants, which is supported by the federal government. It is also a matter of including the men - the men who exercise this violence - and trying to train them accordingly that they should not do it. So no cultural protective cloak over the men, as the colleague had said. And that's good.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Mr President, we welcome the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, but, Commissioner, we believe that the European Union must move from words to actions.We women want to live, we want to live a life without violence, so we wait without delay for a European directive to reinforce the fight and the fight against macho violence.We ask Member States to thoroughly assess the application of laws to see what doesn't work.It seems to us essential that all people who have to implement legislation against gender violence have training in gender issues.It is the only way for machismo not to stick to the implementation of laws.We want to make sure that cases like Joana Rivas never happen again and that no woman has to face prison for not wanting to hand over her sons and daughters to her abusive parents.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, I strongly condemn violence against women, consider it completely unacceptable and call for instruments to combat violence against women to be applied more consistently. The Istanbul Convention in many parts sharply violates the principle of subsidiarity by not adopting at the same time an effective and innovative instrument for combating violence. This is the first international treaty of the Council of Europe in the drafting of which the member states did not participate. Half of the Member States of the European Union have not ratified the Convention and we should ask ourselves why this is so. The definition of gender as stated in this convention assumes that a man is not born as male or female, but that his “gender” is a matter of his personal choice. This is contrary to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court, which says that gender refers to two sexes - male and female - which is to date the only international legally binding definition. We can combat violence against women through appropriate upbringing in families, education in schools and taking concrete measures in the Member States, rather than introducing new ideologies.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to emphasize that I strongly agree with the Commission's proposal that the EU should accede to the Istanbul Convention. The interim report rightly calls on the Member States to ratify this convention, which has already been signed by all Member States, but only 14 have ratified it. Unfortunately, my country, Hungary, has not yet done so either, as the government does not put this issue on the agenda, despite many Hungarian parliamentary initiatives. So, we need to do more. For years, more than a thousand women in the EU have been beaten to death by their husbands, partners or relatives. And that’s just the number of domestic violence, which is more than - shocking, but I have to say - more than the number of victims of terrorism, which is also terrible.
