Finally - and Commissioner, I turn to you - the main message of today's debate should be clear: let there be zero tolerance for violence against women, let this be the first step on this path, and let me personally go even further, let there be zero tolerance. violence against women, children and the elderly. Finally, a personal sentence: I am delighted to have been able to give this speech on the birthday of my beloved wife, Xenia.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the family is the foundation of society.Unfortunately, in some cases, the family home turns from a shelter into a dungeon.We must guarantee help and safety to victims of domestic violence, regardless of gender or age.As a police officer, I have intervened in domestic violence and advocate a zero tolerance rate.The same goes for violence against women.A woman must have the right to choose when and with whom she will have sexual intercourse and how she will protect herself.While deciding only on her own body and not on the lives of others, a woman should have full control over her decisions.Everything else in the report - from advocating abortion, promoting gender ideology to imposing political correctness - does not serve to prevent and sanction violence, but to spread the liberal agenda and silence those who disagree.The ideology whose main goal is the destruction of the traditional Christian society cannot have my support, and I hope the support of the Government of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: - Mr President, violence against women constitutes a brutal form of discrimination and a violation of human rights that occurs in all countries of Europe. One in three women in the European Union has been a victim of physical or sexual violence since the age of fifteen; one in twenty women has been raped; more than half of the women have suffered sexual harassment; one in three women has suffered psychological abuse from her partner; one in three women has suffered physical or sexual violence by an adult during childhood. And those who have had the worst luck have been murdered, in many cases together with their children. On behalf of all of them, of the victims, I congratulate the Commissioner, my colleague Anna Maria and all of us who have worked to achieve EU accession to the Istanbul Convention, an effective instrument to prevent violence, to protect the victims and to prosecute the aggressors; a great step of the many more that we have to continue taking at national and European level and take it all together. I would like to tell the colleague that, on the occasion of this report, she complained about the PP deputies that - as Anna Maria has said - she does not know that there are many deputies in this House of the Popular Party like me, like Anna, like Barbara, that we have been working here for many years for the defense of women and I do not allow my party or us to be questioned.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, after years of talking and endless calls for the EU to accede to the Istanbul Convention, I am very glad the time has finally come. However, beyond tomorrow’s vote, we must call for the Convention to be implemented in full and without reservations and also call for all EU Member States to do the same, including my own country, the UK, which has been dragging its heels. It is, colleagues, more urgent than ever to tackle gender-based violence. Sadly, we have seen a recent wave of attacks, intimidation and harassment of women in politics and in the public sphere, from the tragic murder of Labour MP Jo Cox in the UK last year to the torrents of online abuse against women in public life that have now become routine. We must address the root cause of violence against women and girls and that is the culture of misogyny, sexism and objectification which, frankly, allows violence to prevail. We must follow up the ratification with an ambitious European-wide strategy on gender-based violence and encourage sex- and relationship-education for mutual, respectful relationships.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman!Ladies and gentlemen!Today's debate on the ratification of the Istanbul Convention was important because it showed the intentions and possible consequences that this - I hope it will not come to - ratification can bring.The proposer of the ratification, Mrs Revault d'Allonnes Bonnefoy, spoke directly that it is the protection of life from birth, the prohibition of the so-called abortion, which is a form of violence that this convention should combat.The same was said by MP Peter Niedermüller, who was more specific because he said outright that he hoped that this convention would be a tool to put pressure on his own country so that it would not protect life from birth.In this context, I would like to ask Commissioner Jourova to make here a clear declaration of respect for countries that protect life from birth in their legislation.We have a right to do so under the Treaties, and that should be the declaration here today.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 74% of European citizens think that gender-based violence is a common phenomenon in their country. Around 25% of women in the European Union have experienced physical or sexual violence. More than one in four Europeans believe that non-consensual sexual intercourse is justifiable. The situation, therefore, is very serious. Yet today there are several national policies to combat violence against women, there are individual legal instruments and, after the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, we have a fundamental tool at our disposal to prevent and combat all forms of violence against women, regardless of their age. and all other forms of categorization. Adequate funds must be allocated to put in place the most effective systems of protection from violence for women, especially girls. Now more than ever there is a need for concreteness. Therefore, without delay, the principles of the agreement must be transferred to the appropriate national regulations and the financial means to be found to make them effective.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, every time we speak here about discrimination and violence against women I have a strong feeling that we can never do enough. But we have to continue what we are doing and I am convinced that the accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention is an important step forward. This is the way that we can better join forces – the EU and the Member States – to come up with a truly efficient and balanced mixture of preventative measures and repressive measures. I want to emphasise that yes, we have to speak also about repression because we speak about crime, we speak about the need to come with an efficient response from the side of the law enforcement authorities in the Member States and to better protect women and children. The Istanbul Convention and accession to the Convention will give us, among many other new things and opportunities, a better way of collecting data and of analysing the root causes of violence against women. Through that we will be able to better understand the role played by women’s economic dependence and this will encourage us to do more in this respect. What is the impact of the passivity of our society? We see that part of our society thinks that it is normal to beat women, that domestic violence is something we cannot eliminate, that violence against women is something that the victims in many cases deserve. This is unacceptable and we have to convince all our society that this is not normal. We will understand better how to assess the influence of alcohol because this is not discussed very often but we see that this is also a big issue. We will understand better how to encourage the victims to go and report to the police, how to get them to trust more the institutions which have been established and which are in the EU to help the victims, because still we see that only about 15-20% of the victims report such violence. We will understand better how to achieve better law enforcement, and here again I speak about criminal law in the Member States. We have to better understand and come up with appropriate action to address violence stemming from bad traditions and so-called culture, which was also discussed here. No culture can be the excuse for violence against women and children. We should do much more to explain to young boys and girls that this is not normal to accept violence, that it is not normal that their fathers beat their mothers, in many cases. We will understand better and we will be better able to measure the trend, because you see that in European society violence is on the rise in general, and we see this trend online. We see the rise of violence against women and bullying and sexual harassment. We see this trend and we need to be able to better measure and to come up with the proper reaction. I strongly disagree that this is an ideological issue. I cannot understand how somebody can look at it from this point of view because violence is a crime, unacceptable according to the law. Murdered women are often victims of sexually-motivated crime. What is ideological about our effort to eliminate this from Europe? I must say in reaction to what Mr Niedermüller said, yes, I am worried about the development in some Member States which are looking at Russia as an example of the way forward. In Russia there is a law which says that the first blow in domestic violence does not count. This is not the way the EU should go in the 21st century. Very often when I speak about how to combat violence against women I have in my speeches the horrifying figure of how much it costs. Some of you mentioned EUR 230 million a year. I am always embarrassed to mention this figure because this is not about the money, this is about the life and health of women and children. Ladies and gentlemen, I can confirm today that I shall remain fully committed to keeping you informed on our progress in this endeavour, but also to sharing the state and results of our on-going actions, including the achievements and experiences from the still-unfolding year of focus actions on fighting violence against women.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, first of all my first thanks will go to Anna Maria Corazza Bildt for this successful cooperation. It was very useful that the two committees FEMM and LIBE come together for the completion of this demanding report. I also thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their work. Together, we have come up with an ambitious text that is up to the challenge. This is a fundamental issue that will have a direct impact on the lives of millions of women, half of our population. In this climate of mistrust, this report proves that the European Union protects its citizens. I also thank you, Commissioner, for your strong and clear commitment and I also call on Estonia to speed up the ratification of the Istanbul Convention by the Union, under its Presidency. There is still a long way to go, however, starting with the assumption that there is no excuse for violence against women and using this or that religion to distract from the real causes of this scourge is simply outrageous. The commitment of the European Union to this Istanbul convention is an undeniable added value and must play an essential coordinating role. Equality between women and men and respect for the rule of law are among our fundamental principles. The fight will continue at all levels, and that has been said by many of the speakers. It is very important that all the States of the Union ratify this convention. And beyond - and I repeat - I am convinced that a legislative act on the prevention and fight against violence against women is the next essential step. A directive would provide common definitions at European level of crimes perpetrated against women and would make it possible to strengthen the application of the convention and translate into concrete measures these provisions which fall within the competence of the Union.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am really glad that we have actually reached a broad consensus across political groups. I thank Christine and all the other shadow rapporteurs. Together we are saying: stop violence against women. We share this common goal: this report is about achieving and increasing more, stronger tools. Our report is a wake-up call to the Member States to do more. The time has come to move from words to action. Member States have to overcome their reservations and speed up the EU’s accession and ensure a broader scope, not only in terms of cooperation in justice and criminal law, asylum and non-refoulement. Some points raised by colleagues: cooperation in criminal law is an EU competence foreseen by the Lisbon Treaty. We already have tools at EU level to deal with serious crimes, trafficking, sexual abuse, protection of victims, and recently even the directive to combat terrorism. I would like to join the call to the Commission to propose a legislative act on violence against women as a way to strengthen our capabilities. I also understand, colleagues, the concerns and the controversy surrounding the word ‘gender’. You know how much, throughout the process, I reached out with genuine goodwill to clarify, bridge the gap and leave no misunderstanding. A definition of gender-based violence, in the Commission, according to the Council of Europe, is ‘violence done to a woman or a girl, just because she is a woman or a girl.’ It is not an ideology; it has no hidden agenda; there is definitely nothing against Christian or family values. I do ask the Commission again to clarify, together with the Council of Europe, this misleading interpretation and engage in dialogue with the Member States on the issues that prevent the full ratification and implementation. And I fully support the work of the Council of Europe GREVIO, but they should speed it up. My last point, Mr President, raised by colleagues, is the issue of migrants also having rights and duties, and having to respect our laws, and religious culture never being an excuse to oppress women. Respect for women should become a social norm, but we can never stigmatise migrants for violence in Europe. Women and girls on the move are actually victims of violence – the slavery of our time. Let us, colleagues, have a special focus on children and continue to put pressure on the Member States. The European Parliament and the EPP will continue to commit to zero tolerance against violence against women, and to keep it at the top of the EU agenda.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Tuesday 12 September 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – ‘Fighting violence against women’ should no longer remain a phrase, but it should be acted upon. Now we have the tools to do so. The Istanbul Convention has the potential to bring about the change in mentality that we need to effectively fight violence against women. Violence against women is not female genital mutilation alone. It is not forced marriage only. It is domestic violence. It is sexual abuse. It is rape. It is emotional violence. It is also what some would not even consider: cyber-harassment, which unfortunately is still belittled as ‘not serious enough.’ This attitude completely ignores the scars left by this kind of harassment. This is also an issue of gender equality. We need legislation and policies that promote equality across the board. We need to publicly debate the topic. We have to stress that harassing, attacking or hitting women is not manly and it is definitely not acceptable.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up. - In order to increase the effectiveness and coherence of policies to combat and prevent violence against women in Europe, as well as gender-based violence, it is necessary for the European Union to ratify the Istanbul Convention. This will ensure better implementation of Union law, EU programs and funds approved in this regard, will contribute to the achievement of objectives such as gender equality, combating anti-Semitism, public health, but also economic growth. For the implementation of the proposed objectives, I support the appointment of a European Union coordinator as its representative in the Committee of the Parties to the Council of Europe, as well as the establishment of an Observatory on Gender Violence, following the current model of the European Institute for Gender Equality It is also necessary to promote gender budgeting as a tool for combating and preventing gender-based violence, as well as providing resources and funding for access to justice for victims.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. – The European Parliament is sending an important message to the world by supporting the EU’s accession to the Istanbul Convention - the first legally binding instrument to prevent and combat violence against women on an international level. Women and girls have a right to live free from violence and the threat of violence. The Istanbul Convention provides a framework to raise standards and improve protections, and will make a huge difference to the lives of so many. I represent Wales, where figures show that reported domestic violence increased by at least 23% between 2013 and 2015. Estimates by the Welsh Government in 2014 show that domestic abuse affects 11% of women each year in Wales. The situation requires urgent action and I urge the Estonian Presidency of the EU to facilitate ratification without delay.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: written. - The last decades show a substantive change in traditional social attitudes regarding violence against women in order to coerce their freedom, and the Istanbul Convention represents a legal manifestation of this revolution for rights. I am concerned, however, that this approach, which has such a broad political consensus, continues to underestimate domestic violence directed against men and boys. The timid recognition that we find in the preamble of the Convention that "men can also be victims of domestic violence" is not developed in the documents and initiatives. This contrasts with the findings of scientific studies, some funded by the European Union –such as the DOVE project– that show a similar proportion by sex of victims and perpetrators in domestic abuse. I am also concerned that the interim report omits or does not adequately highlight domestic violence directed at boys, referring three times to 'women and girls' in settings where we also routinely encounter male victims.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. - Violence against women, unfortunately, has not yet disappeared from our societies. The figures speak for themselves, as one third of all women in Europe have been physically or sexually abused at least once in their adult lives, 20% have been harassed online, one in twenty women have been raped and a percentage more than one tenth has been sexually abused using physical violence. The Istanbul Convention follows a comprehensive and targeted approach to tackling violence against women, which is a violation of human rights and an extreme form of discrimination. It focuses on issues of violence against women and girls, including domestic violence, while promoting the rights of victims. EU accession to the Istanbul Convention provides a coherent European legal framework for preventing and combating violence against women, but it is not a panacea, as it does not relieve Member States of the obligation to ratify the Convention at national level. We must immediately put an end to all forms of sexual violence, otherwise our societies will have failed to fulfill their highest duty, which is to protect citizens and their rights.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: in writing. - The Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence (known as the Istanbul Convention) raises a lot of controversy in various communities. Let us stop, however, ascribing ideological overtones to individual articles of the convention. Women have the right to choose the life they want, they should not be stigmatized, pointed out or offended. They have the right to decide about their body and their future. Everyone will immediately admit that they are against violence against anyone, but certain stereotypes still determine women's lives, forcing them into predefined social roles. Physical, psychological and economic violence against women cannot be kept silent. Assistance to victims of sexual crimes, prosecution of perpetrators as well as education and measures against violence are comprehensive solutions provided by the convention and recognized at the UN forum as the golden rules of anti-violence policy. Therefore, I support the accession of the European Union to the provisions of the Convention which concern its competences, that is cooperation in the field of justice and asylum. I also hope that states that have already declared or ratified the convention, such as Poland, will not withdraw - under the influence of various ideologies - their support for this text and will implement its content.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the report by Julie Girling, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS): continuing the current reduction in aviation activities and preparing for a global market-based measure from 2021(COM (2017) 0054 - C8-0028 / 2017 - 2017/0017 (COD)) (A8-0258 / 2017).

name: Julie GIRLING
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, aviation accounts for approximately 2.1% of global CO2 emissions. In the EU, direct CO2 emissions from aviation account for approximately 3% of the total. With the anticipated growth in air traffic, emissions in 2050 are expected to be seven to ten times higher than in 1990. This is according to the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and their projections. Clearly such a growth necessitates a policy response. In this Parliament we have taken the view that we must reduce the carbon impact of the growth in air travel. We all know the history of how we arrived where we are with ‘stop the clock’, so I do not intend to expand on that, but I do want to emphasise Parliament’s commitment to working with ICAO to find a mutually acceptable position.  To this end, during 2016, I led three separate delegations from Parliament to ICAO in Montreal. This represents an unprecedented level of commitment from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and we were very pleased to see an agreement in October 2016 to establish an offsetting system to deliver carbon neutral growth in the aviation sector. As a consequence, the Commission was required to adopt a proposal for a regulation amending the 2003 Emissions Trading System (ETS) Directive with respect to aviation and this was presented earlier this year.  Since then we have moved at a fast pace in Parliament with a view to reaching an agreement between co-legislators before the end of this year. Under the EU ETS aviation provisions – they have never applied in their original international scope due to legal challenges by third countries on the applicability of EU legislation to their airlines – only intra-EEA flights are fully covered.  In its proposal, the Commission extends this derogation beyond 2017 and there is clarity about the new ICAO offsetting scheme and how it should apply to international flights when it enters into force in 2021. Moreover, the Commission text includes a review clause requiring it to report to Parliament and the Council on relevant developments in ICAO’s work and, if appropriate, propose to amend, delete or extend the derogation. In my report I fully support the Commission’s approach, namely that we await progress on the global market-based measure (the GMBM). It is untrue and misleading to imply that my report does not take this position. As the rapporteur, I have proposed to augment the original proposal by adding a time limit on the latest derogation, aligned to fit with ICAO’s own decision—making deadlines. This reflects legitimate concern over the GMBM and whether it will deliver on its commitment to ensure carbon neutral growth from 2020.  At present, based on the current negotiations within ICAO – and they are very current and going on as we speak – progress on the offsetting provisions has been painfully slow, with some parties – and I mention China in particular – now objecting to ICAO’s role in setting the rules for the GMBM.  I believe it would be remiss to make a decision on the future of the ETS in support of a GMBM that is, for the time being at least, vague and imprecise in its framework. A time—limited derogation is therefore required to maintain political pressure on the Council, and indeed the Commission, to develop a long—term regulatory solution. We must learn from the issues encountered with previous iterations of the legislation and provide the sector with much needed investor certainty as soon as work is completed on the GMBM’s reporting provisions on the transparency and the environmental integrity of the offset registry.  The Environment Committee’s report also provides for the designation of revenues generated by auctioned allowances to climate finance, aircraft design and fuel-efficient technologies, plus a schedule for the Commission’s review report and what it needs to include as a minimum, as well as stressing the need for enhanced transparency of ICAO’s work in preparing and implementing the scheme. The report carries over amendments pertinent to the aviation sector in the wider ETS Phase IV proposal, including an increase in the number of auctioned allowances, provisions already voted on in this House.  For all these reasons, I think it is vital that Parliament pursue the time limit on the derogation. Details of the scheme from ICAO are not well enough advanced to be able to say with any certainty that they will be exactly as we currently see them. ICAO is a large international organisation with almost 200 member states and their internal negotiations are not yet complete. I do not believe that Parliament should be complicit in undermining our own negotiating position and recommend that we vote accordingly.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a pleasure to be here today and to take part in your deliberations on the proposal on the European Union emissions trading system for aviation. I appreciate the hard work of the rapporteur Ms Girling on this proposal and would like to thank her for her efforts. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their valuable contributions and their support for a swift and a smooth process. Aviation greenhouse gas emissions are growing sharply and clearly have the potential to put at risk the achievement of the climate targets we committed to in Paris two years ago if they are not adequately addressed. The European Union has taken the lead in addressing these emissions by covering them under its Emissions Trading System and is also working hard at the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) for effective global measures. Precisely, this Commission proposal we are debating today follows the adoption by the ICAO Assembly in October last year of a resolution on the so-called CORSIA (Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme), a global measure to offset aviation emissions beyond 2020 levels after many years of efforts and following up on the Paris Agreement sealed a year before.  As we already recognised, this was an important and welcome first development to address aviation emissions globally, despite being below the European Union ambition. We must acknowledge, however, that a lot of work is still needed to make CORSIA operational by 2021, namely, agreeing the CORSIA rule book in the form of standards and recommended practices presently under negotiation in Montreal and then the adoption of national measures for its concrete implementation. The Commission proposal duly takes this dynamic context into account. First, to facilitate the operationalisation of CORSIA, it maintains the intra—EEA scope for aviation from 2017 onwards. On the other hand, the proposal foresees a new review once there is more clarity as regards international developments for the operationalisation of the global scheme, namely, ICAO rules and how they will be implemented. And finally, it contains an empowerment to adopt delegated acts on monitoring, reporting and verification of emissions in order that the European Union is ready to implement CORSIA in that regard. I want to remind you all of the imperative need for swift progress on this file, paving the way for a final text before the end of the year. If the amendment to the Directive does not enter into force by early 2018, the full scope, covering all flights to and from third countries, will kick off again, and this situation will be problematic.  I would like to underline as well that, in our view, extension of the intra-EEA scope, combined with a review, will allow the European Union to rightly deal with the situation we will face in the coming years. On the one hand, we need to facilitate international developments and get ready to implement CORSIA. On the other hand, we will have to discuss the future rules for the European Union ETS in a context where CORSIA becomes a reality.  I am glad to see that the report you are voting on today shares this basic approach of continuing the intra-EEA scope, to then undertake a new review once there is more clarity on international developments. Let me, however, provide some comments on two key aspects of the rapporteur’s final proposal which raise some concerns on our side.  First, I would like to warn against an automatic return to the full scope right after 2020 in the absence of a new review. That threat could create difficulties with third countries which are now positively involved in ICAO negotiations and are a priori committed to CORSIA implementation. Let’s face it. ICAO has been given little time to complete the negotiation process and it will need to be followed by domestic implemented measures.  We in the European Union are well equipped since it will have to take place through the ETS, but others have much more to develop domestically. So one cannot exclude some delay in the operationalisation, but this would not by itself be enough in our view to trigger an automatic return to full scope and thereby lose years of efforts in the ICAO. In addition, the automatic snap-back to full scope as soon as in 2021 would put the European Union in a difficult and time-constrained situation again when we undertake the necessary review, making it more difficult to duly take into account and discuss all the intricacies of the post-2020 period.  Even in the best case scenario, let us remember that compliance with the so-called ‘pilot phase’ obligations will only happen in 2024, at least if all goes as planned and there are no delays. We may need, therefore, some time to have a clear picture of how CORSIA performs and delivers. We have to bear in mind as well that in the context of the future review we can always decide to go back to a wider scope or cover certain routes to third countries in the light of the international situation at that moment. But this is something that would deserve appropriate analysis and decision at the right time once we know whether and how CORSIA is implemented. My second comment is on the rules for the period up to 2020. We understand the willingness to strengthen the system and bring it closer to the regime for stationary installations. That said, our view is that these aspects should be addressed in the next review, taking due account of the need for aviation to contribute its fair share at European Union level. Anticipating this now could be premature. In that context, we welcome the amendments aiming at better framing the review. We believe that this is the right way of addressing some of the concerns over the future regime. The Commissioner is encouraged by the quick progress achieved on this file and is confident that an agreement on this proposal could be reached this year. I look forward to continuing to work with you on the ETS aviation proposal and bringing it to a successful conclusion.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. - Mister President! The Industry Committee has considered the issue and broadly supports the Commission's position. We have tabled a few amendments, but we fully support the essential point that we want to prevent distortions of competition to the detriment of European aviation and therefore rely on international agreements. We are also opposed to the old system coming into force again in 2020 - if the negotiations do not move forward sufficiently quickly. In this respect, the industry committee supports the rough line. However, we also want to ensure that the Commission does not simply adopt a delegated act when implementing further legislation, but that Parliament continues to be fully involved in proposing the details. And we want to check whether, in the event of failure, CORSIA can also come into force at the same time as the European system. This is an attempt, I don't know if it will succeed. But if we increase the pressure, this report can bring temporary progress for the European aviation industry and at the same time it will increase the pressure on international negotiations. In this respect, the Industry Committee passed its opinion with 51 votes in favor, 5 against and 0 abstentions.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, first I would like to thank my shadow rapporteurs on the Transport Committee and other Members who have been extremely supportive of our position. The Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) has supported for many years a single, global emissions scheme. It is imperative, Commissioner, that the EU allows time for the ground-breaking International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) negotiation discussions to be concluded. As we know, constructive talks are already underway and it is vital that countries such as the US, China, India and others are included as they are major players in this field. I would note that the US can still be part of CORSIA as neither the aviation nor the maritime sectors are included in the COP. To avoid duplication and excessive bureaucracy, the global scheme must include all international intra-EEA and domestic flights. To date, as you know, more than 70 countries have voluntarily signed up to the scheme, which between them emit nearly 90% of aviation CO2 emissions worldwide. We believe that all future revenues should be ring-fenced by Member States, and must be reinvested by an R&D project, such as Single European Sky, Clean Sky, SESAR and others. To avoid the risk of a future snapback to the EU emissions trading system (ETS), which severely damaged our international relations and our aerospace industries, it is vital that our proposed TRAN text amendments be supported. This will be the best opportunity that we have had for the European Union to be part of a global solution, supported by Member States, the Commission, including Commissioner Bulc, and industry, and bringing all key world players onside. Of course, Commissioner, it is absolutely vital that we stop the clock.

name: Peter LIESE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! In the last few days we have unfortunately had another sad occasion to talk about climate change. It cannot be said that individual natural disasters are directly caused by climate change, but the floods in South Asia and the hurricanes in the Caribbean and the USA show that we have a problem here, because all serious researchers say: Such events increase when we are not doing anything about climate change. And now they say when it comes to air traffic, that is only two percent or, in the EU, only three percent. But first of all, the proportion is growing, and secondly, you have to put that into perspective: if you add up the emissions of the 129 countries that committed themselves in Paris - and that includes the member states of the European Union and other industrialized countries - then you get there to the same value as for international air traffic. So we have a problem here, and that's why we have to tackle it, preferably internationally. But this Parliament said a few months ago on CORSIA and said: This is disappointing, it is not yet what we need to really tackle the problem. But to restore the original area of ​​application now would destroy this delicate plant and would also not be feasible. I would therefore like to thank Julie Girling for her work and for what I consider to be a balanced report in many parts. We as the EPP would like to make this even more balanced. For example, with Amendment No 36 we tabled a compromise between ENVI on the one hand and ITRE and TRAN on the other. And I ask my fellow Members to follow the EPP line, and then we will have a good compromise. Finally, a word on Amendment 47: This is about Brexit. Of course we don't want a hard Brexit. We want Great Britain as possible remains in the internal market, definitely in the ETS.But unfortunately we have to be prepared, what you are hearing at the moment is not so positive.That is why we want to prepare for Amendment No 47 and ask you to support us there too.

name: Seb DANCE
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to also join in thanking Rapporteur Girling for the excellent work that has taken place amongst all the groups. I think we have here a very balanced report and something that reflects the consensus on an issue as serious as this. As Mr Liese has just pointed out, we are no longer in a position where we can pretend that climate change isn’t happening. We are all very privileged in this place to be able to do something about it and we will not be thanked by future generations if we stand idly by. The truth of course is that many, many sectors are reducing their emissions but it is not the case in the aviation sector. The global-based market solution does make sense on paper and as many of the colleagues here who joined me and others on the trip to Montreal will know, the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) is very good at handling this process and we have a lot of faith in its ability to take us forward, but we do need that added pressure. We cannot just sit back and hope for the best and think that the carbon neutral growth proposed from 2020 will be sufficient. We have to see what the proposals will look like in concrete terms, and that is what this report does, of course, it gives the Commission the criteria to judge the success or otherwise of ICAO’s process and it does, of course, send a strong signal that we do not want to undermine Parliament’s existing stance on Phase 4 of the Emissions Trading System. Our group supports this proposal and I hope very much that Parliament’s vote will reflect the strong consensus that we have been able to achieve.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - To achieve the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement, all sectors must make an effort, including the aviation sector. And my delegation has always been in favor of including aviation in the emissions trading system. We were much less satisfied with the exception for international flights. After all, this exception is detrimental to the climate, it is detrimental to the environment. Today, however, there are two new important elements in this file that justify a final extension of the exception for international flights. Firstly, there is indeed the ICAO agreement of October 2016 that we want to give every chance for success. And secondly, Parliament is finally making it clear that this last exception for international flights will end by 2020 at the latest. This way we keep the pressure on the kettle and the big stick behind the door. I would like to congratulate my colleague Julie Girling on her thoughtful approach and we will fully support her report.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, what a moment to discuss this important file. As we speak, the results of climate change are hitting the Caribbean with unprecedented force. The central question today is of course: how do we judge the ICAO decision to tackle the problem of climate change? Is it the strong and decisive step of the aviation sector to freeze its emissions globally at 2020 levels and compensate for all additional emissions, or is it a cunning attempt by the aviation industry to buy more time and to accommodate unlimited growth in the future? I think it is neither of the two. My judgment is that it is a promising step forward, but at this stage, it is still limited to an intention. It is based on a resolution, and in the coming years it will be implemented on a voluntary basis. Rules on the global trading registry, criteria for offsets and monitoring of emissions still have to be agreed and implemented by participating countries. It is clearly promising, but at a very early stage. A lot of work and conviction is still necessary to make it a success. Political pressure will be greatly needed, and the question is whether that is by a time limit on the derogation or an indefinite limit on the derogation. I strongly support Julie Girling’s report on this. We very badly need a time limit on the derogation in order to make the ICAO process a success.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your good cooperation in many committees. I think it is important that we are able to find a global, common solution to the issue of CO2 emissions from aviation. Why so? However, as the agreement of the details of the global emissions compensation scheme CORSIA in the negotiations of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) is a matter that will potentially lead to the best outcome in terms of climate, humanity and aviation. I actually got a few of the negotiations with regard to the ICAO and found it, that's what more directions will be challenged in a positive way, the better off we go forward in the spirit. All the different pressure movements have wanted to lead to the formation of different blocks that prevent the process from proceeding properly. The most sensible thing in this case is to move forward together in the spirit of CORSIA. The international compensation system must be as wide-ranging, non-discriminatory, environmentally and climatically efficient as possible, and that work is a smart support for all of us.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, it feels a bit like Groundhog Day here, since we are discussing aviation and climate change again and again. For those who are not aware, back in 2008 the EU promised – with unanimous support from the Council – to get aviation to fall within the scope of the Emissions Trading System (ETS) by 2012. This is for those who say that we have to take our time, and to the Commissioner who said: ‘well, let’s see how we judge the International Civil Aviation Organisation’s (ICAO) progress.’ In 2012, we had already said that it would fall within the scope of the ETS. Then we were promised by ICAO that there would be a global deal in 2016. Yes, that global deal is there, but we have not seen anything yet on how it will work. It is carbon-neutral growth, so that is far from being enough for implementation of Paris. For those who say that aviation is not falling within the scope of the Paris Agreement: that is nonsense, because the Paris targets are economy-wide. Every sector has to work, and until now we have had discussions on many sectors that needed to deliver, aviation was always out and they are still out.  What we are seeing now is that it is finally time for ICAO to live up to its promises, but then they really have to make sure that their so-called compensation projects are really compensation and not just fake, as the case could be. In that sense, it is about time for aviation to pay for its emissions like all the other sectors. We have given them enough time, and now we are going to do it again until the end of 2020? How long are we going to have that debate and give them a free ride?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, the fact that there is currently a debate on reducing carbon dioxide emissions from aviation is in itself extremely positive. With the rapid growth of air transport in recent years has created an additional serious risk to the environment and unfortunately there are no easy solutions. All estimates predict that the number of flights will increase even more in the near future, while technology does not currently offer us a viable alternative. Regarding the emissions trading system, I have said many times that it is not a real solution. In fact, it simply conveys the problem and postpones its treatment. In addition, with the growth rate of most of the third countries, this system will soon become meaningless. In practice, it becomes a purely revenue-generating instrument, with no particular environmental impact. Only a technological revolution will solve the problem. So I want to believe that the proceeds from the rights auctions will go to research and technology development. Until then, however, it would be good for all of us to limit air travel to a minimum, choosing modes of transport that are more environmentally friendly.

name: Ivo BELET
text: - Julie Girling has summarized it perfectly: aviation is on its way to great exponential growth in emissions as a result of the great expansion in the coming years. So I think we can all agree that aviation inevitably needs to make a greater environmental effort. But of course we should not do that blindly. The measures that are now before us guarantee that the competitiveness of European aviation companies remains intact and they create - that is actually not much said here - perhaps also room for those industrial sectors that do need to make efforts on the ground and that are confronted with that. fierce international competition, to perhaps relieve it somewhat. It is also a message to consumers. Some say ticket prices will skyrocket. I think we all know that's not the case. One speaks of 1 to 2% extra cost for the travelers, for the tickets. So I think we know that travelers too, that consumers too are convinced that aviation and that we all have to make an effort, precisely to make the Paris Agreement a success. Aviation can no longer escape this.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Mr President, the Paris Agreement requires action from all sectors and aviation should be no exception. This is amply evident at this point in time with all the natural events happening around us right now. The emission reduction and efforts that different EU industries make should be brought in line and the aviation sector has to take its share. A sound comparison of the overall ambition of the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) with the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) is required and this can only be done against definite and agreed criteria. Only through this can we ensure and determine an adequate scope for 2019. It is high time also for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) to prove that it is a proactive stakeholder, that can adopt effective climate measures that can be implemented by the industry and will really make a positive difference. Here is a sincere appeal for more transparency. Only full transparency can ensure trust and put everyone’s mind at rest on the reliability and quality of the information provided. I understand that the airline industry, like many other industries, operates on thin margins and obviously needs to stay on top of any financial risk. This is the balancing act that needs to be achieved as more industries understand that they need to act and invest now to be prepared for the upcoming challenges.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: - Mister President! It is somewhat unusual for a liberal to start with a left colleague's argument. But I have to say what Merja Kyllönen said I can fully underline. Merja said: We need an efficient, environmentally friendly, global - she didn't say global system, I added that - and it is worth fighting for. I think we all see it that way, that we need it - also for air traffic, for emissions - especially now in view of the bad things that happen to people in the Caribbean. That is a climate change impact that we must address - quite rightly. The EU has been a pioneer in an EU ETS system for 10 years and has thus triggered this global discussion. But we noticed that there was no point in forcing others. There was the Moscow Declaration in 2012, in which even Obama and the US Congress and Russia resisted the EU dictating how things should proceed. We have to see now: the climate is best helped when we actually have a global system. Like the Commissioner, I fear that we will endanger this if we try too hard to use the other thumbscrews now. That's why I'm in favor of the ITRE and TRAN variants.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Mr President, reducing emissions from aviation is one of the biggest challenges facing European environmental policy today. This is the sector that is growing the most in terms of emissions, from 1.5% in 1990 to 4.5% in 2015. The European Union has not taken aviation into account in developing an effective climate strategy, and moreover sought to liberalize the sector as much as possible. How successful can European Union policies be if they do not address such important issues comprehensively, but choose which ones they want to address and which they do not? If we do not act now, at this moment and immediately, there is a risk that emissions from aviation will increase by up to 300% by 2050. Then it will be difficult to fulfill the Paris Climate Agreement, in which the European Union itself and we have all put so much work and hope. Please, finally let's just stop talking and start doing something. Aviation must be part of the system, aviation must be part of the European Union's environmental strategy.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: - We are talking tonight about a sensitive but also ambitious file, especially when it comes to the transport sector. We have promised each other that we will reduce emissions whether transport is covered by COP21 or not. We want to realize that ambition. But we have a difficult relationship between Europe and the rest of the world. On the one hand, we encourage ICAO with the CORSIA approach. On the other hand, we do not want flights from third countries in the EU to disrupt its own EU rules. And let me be clear, may the EU lead the way? Gladly. Can the EU encourage, even force ICAO? Fine, but ultimately no European Alleingang. I have no more beautiful word than this German word: no Alleingang and that is also the way in which we dealt with the stop-the-clock file within the Transport Committee. Let us be ambitious, let's be clear, but also, for example, to the Gulf States, not Alleingang, to ensure that Europe does not suffer, but continues to play a leading role.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the global reduction of national greenhouse gas emissions is a fundamental objective of European Union policy. In this sense, the ETS is an essential tool for an economically efficient reduction of these emissions. The regulation needs to be approved swiftly, given the current uncertainties within ICAO regarding the adoption of a global measure to address the rise in emissions globally. We need to provide legal certainty and clarity to aircraft operators and at the same time comply with the compliance obligations under the EU ETS. The full implementation of the single European sky will also be important for achieving the objectives set by the Paris Agreement and for the 40% reduction of greenhouse gases by 2030. This is essential to avoid fragmentation of the airspace and to optimize the flow of traffic, with consequent benefits for the environment.

name: Markus FERBER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I am a little surprised that there is only one system for reducing CO2 emissions that is at the fore today, namely certificate trading, although a number of other options are available in aviation that have also been used in the past . So please don't lie to each other that nothing would work in aviation without ETS. New engine technologies, new aircraft with completely new wing technologies that are quieter and lower in emissions: a European airspace would do a lot to ensure that we have fewer CO2 emissions. Or investments in infrastructures, as I am now experiencing in Frankfurt: In the past, you could admire Frankfurt from all sides when you flew to it. It has been significantly reduced by building a new runway. All of these are measures that reduce CO2 emissions. In addition, we have to be careful that we as Europeans are not so much role model that nobody wants to follow. And that's why we stopped the clock because the third countries did not want to follow suit and because we wanted to impose a system on them that does not really help to reduce emissions in relation to the measures that I have named. That is why it is right to keep stopping the clock until everyone participates, but of course also to make an effort to ensure that everyone participates. That is the approach that we have advocated in the Committee on Transport and I hope that it will also find the necessary majority in the votes tomorrow. Take responsibility, but internationally!

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, largely absent from the Paris Agreement, air transport is nevertheless the most polluting mode of transport per passenger and per kilometer traveled. In fact, a return flight from London to New York represents as many CO2 emissions as heating a house with fossil fuels for a year. With a traffic growth rate of 5% per year, polluting emissions from air transport could be multiplied by at least three by 2050. We therefore need to adopt a global regulatory mechanism to offset the increase in these emissions. CO2 emissions from airlines. Unfortunately, the CORSIA mechanism will not be legally binding until 2027. Faced with this climate emergency, we must therefore, Commissioner, limit the extension of the “Stop the clock” to 2020, it will - I believe - to the defense of the fight against climate change for Europeans and, beyond that, for all those who are subject to these climate changes.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the air transport sector must make an adequate and effective contribution to achieving the climate objectives of the Paris Agreement.Aviation is currently responsible for 4.5% of emissions within the EU, emissions that will continue to rise if nothing is done.The CORSIA system proposed by ICAO, moreover of a voluntary nature, currently has many unknown limits and aspects.We need more transparency: well, therefore, the proposal of the Girling rapporteur, who sets precise dates and methods for periodically updating Parliament.Crucial is the request to the Commission to propose measures to address the effects of aviation on the climate due to nitrogen oxides and contrails, as well as CO2.Furthermore, the Commission is asked to encourage research on the use of photovoltaic energy and fuels in the aviation sector ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Aviation is the sector where the growth of greenhouse gas emissions is the fastest.If we are talking about two to three percent on a global scale, five percent on a European scale, we must be aware that this is about a quarter or even a third of what agriculture creates, which feeds all of humanity.It is therefore essential that the aviation sector also approaches the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, as already discussed today and also as the report states and as the Commission's position is very clear, Europe as the one leading this pioneering battle in the field of the environment., alone cannot win in this area.That is why I support the direction of the report, the direction of the Commission, that we are trying to use our example and active work to win over those who are the biggest polluters in this area, that is, the United States, China and India.We can be successful together, but we must be leaders in this ourselves.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Mr President, I would also like to remind you that aviation activities are an important factor in greenhouse gas emissions and their level is constantly increasing, despite some good practices by some major airlines.  Various reports, such as the one on the aviation strategy for Europe in 2016, and the connected opinions, such as the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, recall that any amendment to the existing legislation on including aviation in the EU ETS can only be considered if the so-called global market—based measure is ambitious and if it can be carried out as soon as possible.  In my opinion, any kind of derogation from extra EEA flights should be limited, for example in time, and the environmental integrity of the new scheme has to be properly assessed before any further derogations from the EU ETS are granted.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, air transport is responsible for 4.5% of the CO2 emissions produced in the European Union. The global measure proposed by ICAO is a first starting point for 191 countries but many aspects of it remain unknown. For this reason, I do not consider it appropriate to further extend the exemption for flights to and from Europe in view of the adoption of a comprehensive draft measure. It will be possible to discuss this when the fundamental details are clearer, such as the quality of compensation, transparency and applicability of the new measure, the so-called CORSIA. The auctioned emissions quota should be increased to at least 50%, given that aviation currently receives 85% of its emission allowances free of charge, despite the impact assessment admitting that the sector does not present any risk of reallocation of emissions. carbon emissions. Keeping aviation in a reformed ETS is an effective tool to ensure that the sector contributes to EU climate policies, as all other sectors are required to do.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - From the very beginning I want to say that I appreciate the work done by the two committees (I am also part of the TRAN Committee), the position of the rapporteur, the caution with which she finalized this report. I believe that none of us in the European Parliament, but not even outside Parliament, is aware that environmental protection is one of the most important issues. But we have to think about how to do it. Of course, every industry is responsible for emissions, so the aviation industry cannot be exempted either. But I think that until we find a way to correlate our bargaining power with non-European countries, because this is a global issue, not a European one, we cannot establish some measures to put the aviation sector in difficulty again. from the European Union. And, therefore, I believe that the report, as it is done and I hope it will be voted, will bring important changes, but in the pace at which we can make the global negotiation, otherwise we will be in an inappropriate situation… )

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, 1/3 of the world's carbon dioxide emissions come from international aviation. In fact, as aviation increases, global carbon dioxide emissions will increase by 700% by 2050. The globalization of the aviation sector requires the international community to formulate a global system for regulating CO2 emissions in this area. So far, however, the United States, China and other international polluters have been deaf and do not come to an international commitment, even at a time when the United States is experiencing significant natural disasters, precisely because of global warming. A coherent international strategy is therefore needed and the amounts that airlines will pay due to the emissions trading should go to research and the creation of clean technologies. In addition, airlines should not pass on their costs to consumers, as this will put disadvantaged remote Union countries, such as Greece, which is dependent on charter tourism.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the debate today and I appreciate the engagement of the Members of Parliament and their commitment to bring this proposal forward in a swift manner. Political pressure has been mentioned by many of you – Ms Girling, Mr Lange, Mr Gerbrandy, Mr Eickhout, amongst others – and it is our intention to keep an ambitious position in the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO). The outcome of ICAO does not fully meet European ambitions. An offsetting mechanism was not Europe’s first option for aviation and we would have preferred a carbon-trading system. But the ICAO process is a complex one and an offsetting mechanism was the maximum our international partners were ready to accept. We are very well aware of the weaknesses of international credits. However, we are working hard in ICAO to define robust eligibility criteria for emission units so only those that deliver real and additional reductions can be used under the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA). We have nevertheless to give CORSIA an opportunity to deliver, and some implementing rules which are still being finalised from several aspects such as monitoring, verification, transparency and eligibility of units or alternative fuels are key for ensuring environmental performance. We need to know the final features of the scheme first and then see whether and how it is implemented by third countries before carrying out a final assessment. As foreseen in our proposal, we will come up with a new review at a new time when there is more clarity on the operation of CORSIA. In that review we will address the post-2020 situation in detail. There was a very specific remark made by Mr Zoffoli related to non-CO2 gases from aviation and their impact on climate. Climate impacts from aviation’s non-CO2 gases are relevant. However, we will still need some research to better know how they operate and what the magnitude is. NOx emissions, water vapour or contrails may have different effects that could result in warming effects, but the magnitude depends also on the altitude or atmospheric conditions. That makes it also difficult to quantify their impact and to address them through market measures. In any case, we remain committed to continue studying the effects of those emissions and assess measures to address them in the most effective manner. I would like finally to thank all of you for taking this important step in Parliament which provides crucial political momentum for this proposal. I am glad to say that the discussions have progressed well in the Council as well, so we should be ready to start the trilogue soon, and the Commission stands ready to engage in the discussions and will do its best to facilitate an agreement before the end of the year.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, it is often said that we are united by more than that which divides us. I think that is the case here, despite two very clear points of view. There is a broad consensus on the need for climate change action in the aviation sector. That is clear. Nobody stood here and said that we should do nothing. The main bone of contention seems to be the timing of – and indeed the confidence in – the ICAO process. So for those of you here who say that we should be cutting ICAO some more slack – and there do seem to be a number of ambassadors for ICAO here with us today – let me just say this. ICAO have known since 2008 that the EU wants to take action and we have been waiting for them to catch up. We have been doing exactly what we have been urged to do today: not leading too fast and making sure that there is time for details to be sorted out. We have been doing that since 2008.  In 2013, they said they would be ready by 2016. In February 2016, I and many colleagues here went to Montreal and they were talking about 2021. By September 2016, when we went back to Montreal, they were talking about a voluntary scheme in 2021 and a possible mandatory scheme five or so years later. Do not underestimate their ability to procrastinate. Please do not throw away our leverage. We have to hold onto it. It would be – and I use this term which I hear all the time in the UK – an act of self-harm to do so. Please, I appeal to colleagues, do not do it. It really will not get us anywhere. We must be firm.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 September 2017.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Norbert Lins, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the inclusion of greenhouse gas emissions and removals from land use, land use change and forestry into the 20130 climate and energy framework (COM(2016)0479 – C8-0330/2016 – 2016/0230(COD)) (A8-0262/2017).

name: Norbert LINS
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Tonight we will be talking again about Europe's contribution to combating climate change. It is about the European contribution to the implementation of the Paris climate protection agreement - all of this in the light of an American president who has denounced the same and in the light of the events of the last few days. Forests play a key role in climate protection. Sustainable forest management is absolutely positive. Put simply: the forest concerns us all. What has happened since Paris? We have started to implement the Paris Climate Agreement, to bring it to life. The forest and its enormous contribution to combating global warming play an important role in this. That is why we are debating LULUCF here and tonight. Behind this abbreviation there is an accounting system for the CO2 uptake and release in forestry and agriculture. What contribution does the forest make? In order to be able to reliably display the contribution made by forests to climate protection, serious and robust accounting rules for CO2 uptake and release are necessary. Last but not least, as a pioneer in this area, Europe has a very important role to play as an international model. This is the only way we can demand the same from other countries - for example Brazil and others. The EU is under special observation - especially with regard to the World Climate Conference in Bonn in November this year. In the LULUCF area there is no potential for reduction, on the contrary, there is enormous potential to counteract climate change. The performance of our forests is absolutely great and must therefore be communicated positively. Active and sustainable forest management must be designed in such a way that it is good for the forest, for the climate and, last but not least, for the forest manager. This law must not demonize that. Especially by far-sighted ones and responsible management, our forests have grown to an area the size of Portugal in the last 25 years. That's nine million hectares after all. Why does the forest have a double positive effect on the climate? As a tree grows, it absorbs CO2 from the atmosphere and stores the carbon. Overall, our forests absorb ten percent of all EU greenhouse gas emissions. Second, the forest supplies wood to strengthen the bioeconomy - wood that is used, for example, in building houses for furniture and in energy generation. Now to my report: As has become clear, I expressly welcome the proposal by the European Commission, but I have made some changes, in particular to the establishment of the so-called forest reference value. I changed the reference period to the years 2000 to 2012, changed the role of the Member States in relation to the Commission, built in flexibility accordingly, doubled the credits for the forest industry and, above all, now tabled a plenary amendment that tries to integrate the reference period with the future policies adopted Member States to agree. I believe that this is a balanced compromise that deserves a majority in Wednesday's vote. I would like to thank everyone: the Commission, the staff, the shadow rapporteurs, for the intensive and good cooperation over the past few months, and I am now looking forward to the discussion.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a pleasure to be here today in the plenary on the LULUCF proposal. This is an important initiative to implement the European Union commitments under the Paris Agreement and to contribute to the domestic European Union 2030 greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. The European Council’s guidance from October 2014 states that the EU target is ‘an economy-wide absolute reduction from base—year emissions’, reaching ‘at least 40% domestic reduction’ and covering all of the EU’s emissions. Contribution from land use and forests in reaching the long—term climate mitigation objectives is critical because of their potential for anthropogenic removal of carbon from the atmosphere. Forests alone currently cover more than 42% of the European Union land surface and have a huge potential for climate change mitigation through additional sequestration and storage of CO2 and through the potential to substitute fossil-based energy and materials. This debate and the vote this week show that the European Union is serious about its international climate commitment under the Paris Agreement. By doing so, Parliament is also making swift progress on one of the key legislative priorities of the Union: under the Joint Declaration of the European Union’s legislative priorities for 2017, the three institutions have agreed that the 2030 climate action proposals are given priority treatment in 2017. I appreciate the hard work of the rapporteur, Mr Lins, on this proposal and would thank him for the excellent cooperation. Many of the key elements of what you are proposing for vote in this House are in line with the Commission proposals, notably on the need to ensure the robustness of the accounting rules, in particular for forestry, and the sustainable management of forests. This is encouraging, as – like in the Commission proposals – this maintains a careful balance between the need to respond to an increasing demand of biomass availability and climate mitigation objectives. I also note your efforts to further strengthen the environmental integrity of the framework by introducing additional safeguards. Let me offer a few comments on the key aspects of the rapporteur’s final proposal. First, the report adopted by the Environment Committee retains the main principles of the Commission proposal on the construction of Forest Reference Levels. However, it modifies the reference period to a more recent one – 2000 to 2012. This period would include policies promoting increased harvesting in the benchmark and risk hiding real emissions of forest biomass. We should instead be incentivising sustainable forest management and we are open on how to address this challenge. However, the use of a more recent reference period risks compromising the environmental integrity of the LULUCF accounting framework. Second, we understand the concerns of some over the proposal’s language on management intensity, especially that of harvests. The Commission proposal is a way to acknowledge that the management intensity of forests must vary, in accordance with the national characteristics of the forest. If forests become older, more trees will reach maturity and increased harvest may be needed. The Commission proposal acknowledges that the future forest dynamics need to be captured in a forward-looking, projected forest reference level and does not fix the harvest to that of the past. The Commission has, for example, even shown that a harvest increase of up to two per cent may be justified in the projected forest reference level, averaged across the European Union. Third, we must also consider this treatment of biomass emissions vis-à-vis the other legislative proposals. Emissions from combustion of biomass under the ETS and the ESR are zero rated. If instead the accounting of biomass emissions is done downstream in these sectors, the administrative and technical burden would be extreme. We need therefore to be pragmatic. A credible, robust approach compatible with the other pillars of the policy is required. Fourth, I note with interest the proposal to give more visibility to harvested wood products. We see that this aspect of LULUCF is positive, not only for the climate, but also for jobs and the economy. That is why it deserved a special place in our proposal, as the only carbon pool with specific rules and a specific article. Fifth, I welcome the specific improvements enhancing environmental integrity, such as the progressive inclusion of wetlands in the accounting scope, as of 2026, and the safeguard discussed of ensuring that the Union’s forest sink does not decrease, compared to the 1990 to 2009 average. Lastly, I note that the report closely tracks the Commission proposal in respect of agricultural land accounting. We are pleased to see that a proportioned and balanced approach seems to have been found in determining flexibility towards the Effort Sharing sectors. The Commission fully supports the efforts of Parliament and the Council to agree on the ETS and non-ETS proposals before the end of the year. On the ETS file we are in trilogue negotiations, and I welcome the renewed efforts to progress there. I look forward to continuing to work with you on the LULUCF proposal and bringing it to a successful conclusion.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. - Mr President, after one of the hottest summers in history, the macro-Indians and the current hurricanes, let's face it: we must be ambitious in our fight against climate change. According to scientists, not exceeding one and a half degrees and, at the same time, protecting the poorest population in this world means generating negative emissions, apart from the use of land and forests, which must not only be used as a mechanism of compensation. Based on that principle, this regulation, pioneer in the world, can set a precedent and become a model for international negotiations. For this it is necessary that the Regulation, in the first place, clearly establishes that the lands have different objectives and that food production, especially in southern countries, has to be compatible with carbon sinks; and, secondly, that it integrates the rights of land tenure and indigenous peoples. Finally, I call to respect the position of the Commission on the Environment: any attempt to downgrade is to go against the Paris Agreement and play Trump's game.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, External Trade, Research and Energy. - Mr President, climate change is increasingly present in our lives. We had the hottest summers, as mentioned, tragic fires, floods, hurricanes, in short, it is the center of our life that is at stake. As rapporteur for the ITRE committee, I have always tried to ensure that we have adequate, robust, solid and fair monitoring so that we can move forward with the objectives of the Paris Agreement. We had immense difficulties with regard, especially, in relation to the reference period. We maintained a division almost until the end, although with agreement on most issues. But the truth is that it is unacceptable that the interests of industry in just one Northern European country could jeopardize, or could put themselves at the forefront, of the interests of all the countries of Europe and their citizens and the common good. For this reason, I call for Mr Lins's report to be voted in favor. He is clearly more favorable than the one who passed the ITRE, for which I myself voted against and I must say, Commissioner, that I still preferred the Commission's version of the reference periods, but that, unfortunately, cannot go any further. .

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture.- The LULUCF regulation talks about the importance of agricultural land and forest use for climate change.Agriculture or vegetation, through photosynthesis, do not use a lot of CO2, on the other hand, and on the other hand, forests also accumulate reserves, which in the end can be a quality source for building materials or even for energy use.In this document, we support the guidelines also given by ENVI, in the direction that great care must be taken in the sustainable use of forests, because an aging forest that is not sufficiently felled can play the opposite role.I come from Slovenia, where in the period 2000-2009 logging was only 37% of the increase.Therefore, such a solution, which also makes it possible to increase logging here, is sustainable, because using it as it has been so far would have the exact opposite effect.I support such a flexible approach and that both the state and the Commission agree on individual uses, as is also possible in the amendments.

name: Peter LIESE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! All sectors have to participate in our efforts to counter climate change, including agriculture and forestry, of course. Therefore, at first glance, it seems surprising that we do not have any reduction targets for emissions here, as we have in industry and in other sectors. But it is precisely because sustainable forestry is already making a contribution to climate protection. From a climate protection point of view and from many other points of view, forest management is something positive, and we want to recognize this contribution. At the same time, we have to be careful that there are no booking tricks. It is not that easy to calculate the whole thing in such a way that everything is really clean. And we don't want to set a bad example for other regions, other countries in the world. If you fully recognize the forest sector, then in a country like Brazil you could say: You don't need to burden your power plants, your steelworks and many other plants with climate targets in any way, and that would be for you the climate bad. But it would also be bad for the competitiveness of the European economy if we were too generous. That is why we need a good compromise. The efforts must be recognized, but at the same time we also need a limitation. I am very much in favor of the Commission proposing a reference period. But I would ask you, like Norbert Lins, to support the EPP amendment that we should handle this a little more flexibly while maintaining the goal.

name: Paul BRANNEN
