text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in July in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety we voted on LULUCF and here the central debate in the committee was around whether we supported the Commission’s proposal to have a historic reference level, or we supported a different proposal coming from a minority of countries and a minority of MEPs for a future reference level. The S&D supported the Commission position and the Environment Committee went on to support the position of the Commission. And now we find ourselves in a strange situation because, having lost the argument about historic reference levels, the minority of countries and the minority of MEPs have come back with a wrecking amendment – a wrecking amendment that would remove the guts, the heart, from the Commission’s proposal. If you remove the word ‘intensity’ from what is in front of us tonight, what is it that you would be measuring in relation to European forests? The whole purpose of the accounting system proposed by the Commission is to measure the intensity with which we use our forests in the future compared to how we used them in the past. So if this amendment goes through, then you take the heart out of what it was that we at the Environment Committee and at the Commission level were trying collectively to achieve. So, please, when it comes to the vote on Wednesday, support the motion as it is, produced by the rapporteur from the EPP. It is a compromise but it is fine, we all agreed it, we can work on it, but there is only one amendment, notice, only one amendment, and that amendment must be opposed because it represents narrow-minded individual country interests. Support the Commission proposal which is for an EU-wide climate change response in line with the Paris Agreement, keeping the word ‘intensity’. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, it is with some surprise that I hear strong words about a few countries. The few countries you are talking about are the few countries that have been managing their forests in a sustainable way for years. I would like to compare the way we have been managing our forests to the way that your country has been performing with your forests. Again we come down to this issue. When colleagues from other countries – which do not have bears, do not have wolves – want to decide what we in Sweden should do with our forests, please explain how your model is better than ours.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: blue-card answer. – This is a debate that we have had throughout the LULUCF discussion. There are two things on the table: there is how we manage our forests, which admittedly is a nation-state responsibility, but there is also how we tackle climate change – and that is an EU-wide responsibility. You have to decide, ultimately, which is more important: individual country plans for forests, or how we tackle climate change collectively at an EU level. I know which is more important. I know which is more important for our children and the future of this planet. I hope that you would realise.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Colleagues! The Paris Agreement was made possible mainly because decarbonization was removed from its final text. It therefore does not blindly promote a radical reduction in CO2 emissions, but instead aims to ensure carbon neutrality, that is, a balance between emissions and the capacity to absorb them. The absorption capacity is largely due to forests. So if we are to be faithful to the spirit of the Paris Agreement, then we must develop policies that promote forest development and responsible management of forest resources. That is why it is so important that LULUCF enables forest management that, on the one hand, ensures the maintenance and development of carbon dioxide-absorbing forest resources, and, on the other hand, does not limit those branches of economies that depend on forestry. Let us remember that forests have been an object of human activity for centuries. Maintaining sustainable forest management is absolutely not in contradiction with the possibility of developing the potential for absorbing forests, therefore the ECR group will support the rapporteur's amendment on forest reference levels as it aims to provide the necessary flexibility.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - (FI) Mr President, sometimes things happen in politics in such a way that a single issue comes to the center of the whole debate and we forget what the whole is. This has also happened in the environmental debate. It seems that we are forgetting that this is a real big entity, of which emissions trading is one part, another is burden sharing, where Finland's burden is moderately large, ie 39 per cent, and the third leg in this entity is LULUCF. I was pleased to note that Commissioner Arias Cañete emphasized that the Commission's intention was not to reduce the Member States' ability to manage their affairs with a responsible forest policy. Prior to this, we also discussed how we can reduce CO2 emissions from aircraft in the future. The only way to go that way is to use forest resources to our advantage to create a fuel that does not pollute our world. Then we will talk about our forest resources - Finland, Sweden, Germany, Poland, Spain and France. The English had a forest sometime in the 16th century - Sherwood Forest - but if my friend Paul Branning goes to see what condition Sherwood Forest is in today, then he will be disappointed. As if to be disappointed.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (FI) Mr President, from the point of view of future generations, we are making big decisions on climate policy. I could only think of my home country, but the risks of climate refugee force me to look wider. The disagreement on the presentation now under consideration seems to be a time span and a logging intensity. For me, the most challenging thing is the whole and managing it, whether or not the global carbon balance is balanced in the short and long term. I do not think that the Commission's proposal was intended to prevent the rational use of forest growth. What is crucial is what forest growth is used for. Sustainable forestry carbon sequestration solutions or solutions that increase overall emissions? I would have liked us to have a debate on the obligation to afforest, to increase the total carbon sink in the EU and globally, a broader analysis of what will replace the fossil economy, what will produce more emissions and what will produce less. We simply need to be able to work together to create a credible climate agenda for Europe. Only then can this planet be viable for children and grandchildren as well.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Colleagues, LULUCF regulation is one of the key issues in European climate regulation, as we know that global emissions have increased by around Forestry and land use change were responsible for 40%. This is how we need to see this regulation as crucial to climate change. At the same time, I often see that when we talk about the LULUCF sector, our approach somehow strangely reverses. Instead of looking at the carbon footprint of forests and land use from the point of view of the climate that we are ultimately impacting, we are debating technical issues, debating technical accounting issues instead of looking at it. how we will ultimately contribute to climate change prevention. The European Commission's proposal is, I think, a good attempt to reach a compromise between different points of view, together with the fact that I could list a number of its mistakes. It doesn’t go far enough in my opinion, but at the same time it is an opportunity to agree on something together. The ENVI Committee's resolution goes one step further than the Commission and authorizes further emissions in this area. However, it is also a step forward. I think that the position of the ENVI Committee is the final minimum that can be gone, and we cannot support any change in this difficult-to-sweat compromise in the European Parliament, and I ask that you do not support it either.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, twenty years ago the first IPCC report on the consequences of global warming painted the picture we see today: increasingly extreme and destructive weather phenomena. We keep repeating that we want to contain the temperature increase within 2 ° C, possibly 1.5 ° C, as signed in Paris, and this is a laudable and necessary attempt but it becomes less credible every day. The uncertainty is total and not only because the commitments, political agreements and reduction targets are inadequate, but also because hitherto unknown risk elements could arise: from the melting of permafrost, for example, which would release the gases previously trapped , of which no one can quantify the extent; or precisely from the soil, which together with the forests, is the subject of the regulation under discussion today. A recent work published in Nature describes a process of acceleration of the release of CO2 from the soil, as a consequence of the greater activity of microorganisms, stimulated precisely by the increase in average temperatures. Researchers estimate that by 2050, at least 55 billion tons of CO2 could be released from the soil not foreseen by the emission scenarios. In this House I have heard hundreds of voices worried about climate change being raised by all political groups: but when it comes to translating proclamations into legislative action I still count many, too many groups, too many colleagues who continue to defend the status quo, postpone, dilute commitments, insert flexibility and loopholes. The text that arrived in the Chamber already represents a compromise to the downside with respect to what scientific evidence and common sense would require. For the 5 Star Movement it is still an acceptable text but it must not be weakened by dangerous amendments, such as the one proposed by the EPP group, which increases flexibility for forests managed, effectively allowing an increase in cutting activities.I urge everyone to ensure consistency between the measures we are voting on here in the Chamber and the political commitments we make.(The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: blue-card question. – You also mentioned a scientific basis for the LULUCF with which I very much agree: we have to look at the whole forest in the world and in Europe. So how can you say that this proposal, which would give for some countries the reference of their yearly increment to remain at 85% and for some countries it is around 40%? What is the scientific reason for that? I do not see there any basis on which we can make this difference between the Member States.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- Perhaps I have not explained myself very well or perhaps we have not understood each other: the scientific evidence concerns what is currently the climate change underway and the urgency that scientific data propose to us on the political action that must be done: and thepolitical action that must be taken, alas, is always too weak.And this is the crucial point, which I believe we must be able to resolve, and I therefore call on everyone again to increase the ambition of the political actions we are taking.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, since the Paris Agreement was approved, you have made several very important proposals to us in the fight against climate change. For example, the Emissions Trading Directive is important, or the Fuzzy Sectors Directive. But this issue is particularly important because it affects forestry and agriculture and, therefore, the rural environment. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, first of all, for the great work and for having been able to reach an agreement that was not at all easy, because there are antagonistic positions within this House and within our own group. And, in addition, it has known how to respect the different types of forests in the European Union. The takeovers made by agriculture, land use and forestry have to be real and they have to be comparable. They have to be real to respect the efforts made by other sectors and to avoid creative accounting, which, moreover, would be a discredit for the European Union in the international arena. And they have to be comparable because it is necessary to be able to quantify the takeovers of each Member State and of the European Union as a whole. Reference periods are absolutely necessary, and they must be rational and consistent. For all this, it is convenient for the European Union - the Commission - to have control over the figures of the Member States. I believe that this Regulation is very important for sustainable economic activities in rural areas, and we have to support it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Mr President, we can all agree that forests are clean and they clean the air. They provide oxygen, raw materials and energy and they are a crucial element to tackle climate change. On the one hand they can cool the climate, but at the same time intensive felling and deforestation can have serious negative climate impacts. We are aware of the important role that forests, land and ecosystems have if we want to reach our Paris Agreement targets. I could not help but follow the negative campaign that has been going on before the vote will be taken during this plenary, and I saw also amendments attacking the delicate position that was achieved in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) on this legislation, and I believe that if we end up adopting a future reference level rather than one based on what is well documented and known, we will end up with a system which will not work and will not address our climate change concerns. The report of the Parliament’s Environment Committee is a step towards a better climate policy. It aims at a robust and transparent accounting system for forestry emissions rather than one which will have the potential to hide emissions from increased forest cutting. Once again we need a strong parliamentary position on LULUCF: one that gives proof of our climate commitment and ensures the capacity of our forests to store carbon.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - I come from Flanders, colleagues, and that is a region that is much less wooded compared to other EU Member States, but we do have some beautiful forest pearls and we know how important they are. In my own city we have the Hallerbos. And the Sonian Forest, which was recognized by Unesco as a world heritage site last summer, is also close to my heart. The forests are so precious, we know. They are a source of tranquility, of recreation, they are a habitat for fauna and flora. Their sustainable management has an economic dimension and they contribute to a better climate and better air quality. Efforts from all sectors are needed to achieve the 2030 target of 40% less CO2. And my party N-VA is also convinced that forestry can and must make an important contribution to climate policy by ensuring less CO2 in the air. That is why we support the ambition to reduce net emissions from forestry to zero by 2030 and to further evolve afterwards towards a positive balance, a necessary contribution to a low-carbon society.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: – Mr President, LULUCF is awfully complex, almost as complex as its abbreviation, but it is very important for all of us. Almost one fifth of all global greenhouse gases come from it. The LULUCF Regulation is not a policy that prescribes in detail what Member States should do with their forests. It does not even regulate whether a government or private company can start or stop harvesting a forest.  LULUCF is an accounting policy. By correctly checking the exact amount of emissions released or absorbed by forests, agricultural land and other forms of land use, we know how much emissions budget is left for other types of emissions. Member States can, on the basis of the account, decide themselves what specific measures they want to take on forest and land use, or on other sectors of the economy such as transport and energy.  Let’s not fool ourselves by tweaking the rules though. LULUCF is like managing your financial budget. It is extremely boring and complicated but crucial to avoid bankruptcy.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: - Mr President, go ahead because I believe that here we all say that we defend the fight against climate change and that this fight, moreover, has to be from all sectors, as is also being done by the Regional Development Commission regarding role of cities and regions. But the solution to achieve a reduction in greenhouse gases is not to juggle numbers and afforest agricultural lands, but to change the current agricultural production model, reduce nitrogen fertilizers, prohibit industrial livestock and agriculture and avoid changes in land use that favor the industrial model is unsustainable, and also put an end to the transformation of food during transport. An abundant forest mass is necessary for many reasons already explained here, but a sufficient amount of agricultural area is also necessary to guarantee food security and sovereignty. There must be a real and urgent shift towards agroecology-based food production and short circuits of food marketing.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, last week I was invited by the Polish Greens to take action against logging in Białowieża forest, Europe’s oldest forest and a vital carbon sink. Whilst the EU is trying to protect this particular forest, it is simultaneously incentivising logging elsewhere in Europe through failing to control land use and biofuels. Enhancing carbon sinks through sustainable land and forestry management has long been recognised as an important pillar of carbon reduction, but the sloppy carbon accounting put forward in this regulation on land use management leaves a gaping loophole which would allow for increased logging in the EU. At the same time, the biofuel industry are pushing for high targets and renewables that would also increase deforestation. We need the EU to show leadership and take our Paris climate targets seriously. When will we wake up to the stark reality of climate change, start protecting our forests and begin to see the wood for the trees?

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: - Mr President! The EU does not and should not have any decision-making power over forest policy. Honestly, I do not even think that we in this room agree on what a forest is for anything. However, the EU makes many decisions that affect forests, not least in climate policy. This is perhaps the most important of those decisions. When we design climate policy, we must use the incredible potential of the forest to combat climate change, but we do not do that today. Most of my colleagues who have now said how to use forests and what to decide and probably do not know even the most basic facts about the state of Europe's forests - that we do not even harvest 60 percent of growth, that forests in Europe grow almost the equivalent of one Cyprus each year. You can thus increase the amount of forest and increase the amount of felling. We have been doing this in Sweden for over a hundred years. That is why we must never set a ceiling on the intensity of forestry. To my Social Democrat colleague from Britain, I would like to say the following: You cut down your forests a thousand years ago and still have not figured out how to get them back. I think there should be room for a little humility when trying to come up with lessons for those who have cared for and developed the forests and got them back, just in the last hundred years. Listen and learn instead!

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: - The land use sector has a profound effect on greenhouse gas emissions and can play a huge role in removing them from the atmosphere. Accounting for the impact of this sector is therefore a key element in climate policy. Without this component we cannot implement the Paris Agreement. We can't even monitor his progress. This legislation will contribute to our international commitments and, in addition, will show and quantify the real value of forests, wetlands and other natural resources. The proposed legislation should encourage Member States to protect their carbon sinks, but flexibility is also important. Emissions from one sector should be allowed to be offset by carbon sequestration from other sectors or traded between Member States, as long as the cumulative effect of these elements of flexibility is to reduce total emissions.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: - (FI) Mr President, the forest laws of the EU and the various Member States ensure that Europe's forests are managed sustainably, respecting biodiversity, which is very important. That is why Europe's wood resources have also grown for a long time and will continue to do so in the future as the climate cools. It is possible for Europe to combine the growth of forest resources with the increasing use of wood. We can replace many climate-damaging fossil products, such as concrete, oil and fuels, with renewable wood-based products. The forthcoming LULUCF vote will decide the future of the European bioeconomy. Proposals from the Commission and the Committee on the Environment on carbon sinks in forests would encourage the freezing of wood use to the level of the past, which does not make sense. Such a calculation method would, for example, make Finnish carbon sinks an emission in climate calculations. We would have to import wood from outside Europe, where the forest may not be managed sustainably. We in Parliament need to understand to look ahead and see the opportunities offered by increasing timber resources. Amendment No 65 by the PPE Group makes this possible, ensuring that forest resources continue to grow in the future. It also encourages member states to use sustainable wood and forestry.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: - Mister President! First of all, I would like to thank Mr. Lins. The Commission's submission has been improved. Of course, agriculture and forestry must do their part. But we have to look at what kind of agriculture we include. Intensive farming is more of a problem. Agriculture that continues to use peatland intensively, for example, is also a problem, or agriculture that contributes to the destruction of grassland. This also releases huge amounts of CO2. The same of course also applies to forestry. Only sustainable forest management can help solve the problem. Forestry that relies on fast-growing trees such as eucalyptus in southern Europe does not contribute to climate protection. We have to make a lot of differentiation. That is why it is important that we support sustainable systems. In any case, there is one thing we must not do: we must not use the LULUCF template as a clearing house and we must not do the math in other areas, while emissions are not reduced in the transport sector, for example. LULUCF is not made for that. We have to make a clean separation here and not use LULUCF as an offset.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, I congratulate my colleague Lins on the report, I thank him for the effort he put into drafting this report as well as for the excellent cooperation. In evaluating the contribution of forests to European energy and climate policies, the possibilities and capacities of the Member States need to be carefully assessed, especially if historical historical management criteria are taken into account. Croatia has almost 50% of the state territory covered by forests and every year it achieves a significant increase in forest biomass. According to Eurostat, the Member States that joined the European Union in 2004 and beyond have raised the level of forest management. Croatia was not able to achieve a higher level of forest management in its entire territory, but only in the territory that it could fully manage. Namely, from 1991 to 1998, due to the occupation of part of the territory, due to the Homeland War that followed, and the process of peaceful reintegration, Croatia could not manage its forests. We are still feeling the consequences of the Greater Serbia aggression today due to the remaining mine resources. Croatia has so far invested over 680m euros in demining mine suspected areas. That demining work was indeed intensive, but there are still 425 km2 left, and it will not be over before the middle of 2019. Over 90% of the remaining mined areas are forests, so I thank my colleague Lins who appreciated all this and made an exception for Croatia.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: - (FI) Mr President, we must meet three challenges at the same time: curbing climate emissions, reforming the economy and industry, and replacing fossil fuels with renewable biomass, including sustainable forest management. The whole will lead to a better fight against climate change. I was the shadow rapporteur for LULUCF in the ITRE Committee. In accounting, we added carbon sinks for our category of wood products. These store carbon and can still replace fossil materials. The ENVI Committee takes note of this, thank you for it. On the key issue of the reference period for forest use, the ITRE Committee wanted to take into account all the information, including the most recent information. Unfortunately, the presentation now on the table is limited to the old period in terms of annual forest use and arbitrary differences between EU countries. At European level, forests must be a drain. Such a proposal between EU countries is unacceptable. The rapporteur's amendment to the vote would make this possible. I ask my colleagues to vote in favor of the ENVI report, but also for clarification. A look at Europe and the creation of carbon sinks, but not on the basis of inequality between Member States.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: - Mr President! Anyone who follows this debate may think that there are a great many here who are opposed to us having calculation bases for the forest's climate impact. That is not the case at all, but what we are talking about are technical details where we differ in the proposal that has come from the Commission. I would also like to remind my colleagues in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy that they have completely forgotten that the Committee on Industry and Agriculture has also dealt with this report by giving opinions. There, the result was completely different. So if you try to make it appear that there are a few members from a few countries who have a different view of some of the calculation bases, then it is not true at all. It is an overwhelming majority in the Committee on Industry and the Committee on Agriculture that has a different focus. When it comes to reference levels and why they are particularly important, it is clear that if we set calculation bases on a historical basis, it means that if we were to look at toothbrush manufacturing and it would apply to how we were allowed to manufacture toothbrushes in the 19th century, then it is clear that we get completely different results than modern technology today.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: - Mr President, from a climate perspective, reducing carbon sequestration is the same thing as emissions. The best and easiest way to sequester carbon dioxide from the atmosphere is to grow carbon sinks, or forests. The new compromise proposal of the European People's Party is unclear. I read it myself so that all forest growth could be felled, and the forest’s carbon sink would be allowed to decrease until 2049. There is no time for this. The implementation of the Paris Climate Agreement is in a hurry, and land and forest use play a key role. Climate change will not be solved by hiding emissions. Accounting must be transparent and honest. The report of the Committee on the Environment does not limit the number of fellings. But the report points in the right direction with economic incentives, namely increasing carbon sinks and more sustainable use of wood. On the other hand, it is not sustainable to seek additional felling to increase forest-based bioenergy in abundance. A sensible circular economy is to get more from less and sustainable, long-lasting wooden buildings, new innovations, replacing plastic with wood.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: - Mr President!In Europe, our main climate goal is to reduce CO2 emissions.We have various resources that can help: sun, wind, water and also forests.If there is a lot of sun in the south of Europe, there is little sun in the north of Europe, but a lot of forests.From the forests we get a variety of products: of course, paper, boards, but also musical instruments, toys, furniture.Very abundant.And it is from waste, so from sawdust and wood chips, that we also get the fuel from which we produce heat and electricity.So renewable energy is on top of everything.Colleagues, we do not need to destroy the European forest-based industry, we need instead to encourage it to develop in a sustainable way, which means that every time a tree is cut down, it is imperative and new to be planted immediately.A felled tree does not necessarily mean a destroyed forest.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, forest environments and their needs differ between Member States.This is what we wanted to state in the report of this house on the new European Forest Strategy.European forests grow in the north but are retreating in the south and, in the face of climate change, Mediterranean forests are in danger of disappearing into ashes.However, there is something common around Europe, and it is the conviction that active forest management produces benefits, both for the economy and for the promotion of rural life and the fight against climate change.For this reason, I want to thank the work of the rapporteur, our colleague Lins, who has made an enormous effort to find the not easy balance between the uncompromising commitment to the Paris Agreements - of which the Union must be the leader and example - andforest activity, which, in the end, are two sides of the same coin.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, forests play an important role in combating climate change, and this is particularly well known in my country, Finland, which is by far the most forested country in Europe. More than 75 percent of Finland's area is forest. Forests also play a very important role in our national economy, and that means that it is also in the interest of all of us to take care of forests in a sustainable way. In Finland, forests have always grown more than they have been felled, and this will continue to be the case. This Commission proposal has caused a great deal of concern and even outrage in forested countries, because the proposal on the calculation mechanism, and in particular the reference years, puts Member States in a very unequal position and even penalizes those Member States that have sustainably managed their own forests. It must also be possible to increase the use of forests in areas where it can be done in a sustainable way and in such a way that forests continue to be carbon sinks. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Lins, for his excellent work, in which he has sought a good compromise, and I suggest that everyone broadly support Mr Lins's amendment, which also makes it possible to develop sustainable forest management.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Forests, as we know, fulfill many functions that have a very positive impact on the functioning of ecosystems, on our lives, but also on reducing CO2 emissions. It is estimated that forests in Europe absorb a tenth of the total greenhouse gas emissions each year, which is a great absorption potential that should undoubtedly be maintained and developed. On the other hand, we must not forget that the forestry sector must also meet the growing demand for wood. The final shape of the regulations that will be passed by us will play a key role in the context of shaping forest management, and will also affect the future and the activities of many entities operating within it and benefiting from its turnover. Therefore, it is important to remember that perceiving forest resources as an effective way to contribute to reducing carbon dioxide emissions can also reduce the burden on other high-carbon sectors of individual economies. It is also important to bear in mind the differences between individual Member States and to support a position that will lead to the implementation of the Paris Agreement in a balanced and comprehensive manner and prevent climate change. This goal can certainly be achieved by integrating forestry, climate and economic policies and creating long-term plans and strategies for European forestry. I am very glad that a significant part of the complex amendments is focused on finding a compromise between the further development of forests, but also between the availability of wood raw material.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Commissioner, this proposal determines how carbon dioxide emissions from the agricultural and forestry sector should be incorporated into European climate policy, in order to contribute to the reduction of emissions in the European Union and is of great relevance in the context international negotiations on climate change by the political signals it emits regarding the European Union's ambition and determination to combat climate change. Forests are closely related to climate change. It is estimated that the climatic impact of past changes in the soil and its cover were responsible for about 40% of the total warming between 1850 and 2010, an astronomical value. It is therefore essential that forests are managed sustainably, maintaining their biological diversity, their productivity, their capacity for regeneration, their ability to satisfy, now and in the future, ecological, economic and social functions. at local, national and global levels. After one of the hottest summers in history and the serious fires that hit Europe - in particular my country - it is important to emphasize the importance of forests in the fight against climate change. I believe that the present proposal - in line with a climate policy that recognizes the role of forests and soil in its key role in combating climate change - may be the only way to safely move towards a resilient energy union endowed with a forward-looking climate change policy that supports its decarbonisation dimension.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, of course I agree with my predecessors that forests play an important role in protecting the climate.Their absorption capacity is truly unquestionable.I would like to emphasize not only the environmental value, but also the economic value.I do not want to question the Paris Agreement at all, that is a very clear commitment from the European Union, and I am happy for it.But I think we need to look for the widest possible compromises in these areas, where the competence lies mainly with the Member States.For this reason too, I would like to agree to the compromise proposal tabled by my fellow rapporteur, Norbert Lins, because it is actually looking for a balanced role between what is our responsibility in relation to the Paris Agreement and what is our respect for the Member States, whichcompetence in relation to forestry.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, COP 23 in Bonn is just a few weeks away and I think that the LULUCF proposal, which we are discussing this evening, could represent an important step forward in the fight against climate change. The objective of the proposal can only be achieved with rigorous and credible accounting at EU level for the period 2021-2030 and if the target of debt-free and possible credits are achieved in a comparable and rigorous manner. Our long-term climate goals are based on net removals in the LULUCF sector but this must not lead to a reduction in the level of ambition in other sectors. A distinction should also be made between green CO2 emissions from the LULUCF sector and emissions from fossil combustion. And to this end, consistency between the various policies of the European Union is essential. The flexibility proposed by the LULUCF regulation is a useful tool to enhance, reward and incentivize forestry and agriculture for their climate smart actions, but we must not let our guard down and we must be ambitious

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, forests cover more than 42% of the European Union's land area and thus make a key contribution to mitigating climate change. This is even recognized by the LULUCF regulation. But this means that measures must be taken to protect forests, to support sustainable forestry and biodiversity. Lately we have had catastrophic fires in Greece, Portugal and other countries in the South. Therefore, firefighting mechanisms need strengthening but reforestation must also take place. At the same time, forest maps should not be drawn up arbitrarily and grasslands and wetlands should also be recorded. Accounting of managed forest areas is necessary, as well as logging products.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: - Mr President, sustainable forest management and responsible forest management are the best climate policies.It also enables responsible forest management.That is why wooded lands also manage their forests.Against this background, the Commissioner's speech seemed rather strange when he was only talking about administrative problems.Great to have balance and a little flexibility.However, the Commission's original proposal was very unequal for the various Member States.It penalized specifically those Member States that have managed their forests and knew how to use them responsibly.Forest policy is not an administrative problem, but forest policy is responsible forest management so that it can be used, but nature can also be enjoyed and the conditions of climate policy can be met.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: - Madam President!The inclusion of land use and forestry in LULUCF, the EU's climate and energy framework, is very positive, but it must be done in such a way that the ambition of the framework is not diminished.A key issue is how the reference level for forestry is set.The regulations must be transparent and robust, at the same time as I still want to see national self-determination in forest issues.We should reduce the production of short-lived forest products and prioritize long-lived products.We must also reduce energy consumption and paper consumption.We will invest in energy efficiency and reuse.I want to phase out clear-cutting and return to close-to-nature clear-cutting forestry methods.We should also promote natural regeneration and increase the proportion of mixed forests with more deciduous trees.I would like to thank Norbert Lins for his amendments, and I am absolutely prepared to vote in favor of them.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, forests, which, as already mentioned, make up 42% of the European Union's area, are an important factor in tackling climate change and mitigating its effects, as they absorb and store about 10% of carbon dioxide, which is one of the greenhouse gases and, in this way, addresses, as I said before, the impact of climate change. In addition, the forest helps agriculture meet the ever-increasing needs for food and feed and provides timber, which is a raw material for the bio-economy. For all of the above reasons, both the individual states and the European Union as a whole should consider and rationalize gastronomy and forestry, so that they get the greatest benefits, not be destroyed by forests and fulfilled the targets by 2030 for tackling climate change.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think the Paris Agreement has had the effect of creating more awareness amongst Member States, businesses, individuals, of the part they need to play in meeting our commitments. I think the agricultural sector is a case in point. A couple of weeks ago I attended an open day in my own country, in Gurteen College, called ‘Energy in Agriculture’, where the amount of innovation that is taking place in relation to trying to reduce emissions and create renewable energies in agriculture was breathtaking. Forestry is a case in point. I think the important aspect is that, while we all know it is a carbon sink and the forests can be used for various products – especially for renewable energy – once we have a policy of increasing (not decreasing) the amount of land under forestry, we can work everything out from there.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - Thank you, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Halting climate change is, without a doubt, one of today's most important challenges. The use of forests as a means of capturing carbon dioxide, even in the most modest estimates, will be cheaper and more efficient than any possible improvements to hydrocarbon engines today. The regulation we are debating today must help and become an excellent tool for halting the impact of forests on climate change. It would be more helpful if the Commission had not made a few mistakes. In particular, it states that, according to her proposal, the forests that grew during the historical reference period in the 1990s and 2000, were climate-neutral. This document has been slightly improved in the ENVI Committee and can already be supported. At the same time, we should not forget that the aim of European regulation in this area must be to strengthen the motivation for both Member States and the rest of the world to grow more forests as a means of curbing climate change. I still miss that in this document. Thank you.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: - Mr President, there is only a minute's time here, and it is perhaps best used with a little emotional speech.This is certainly a good and right thing to do.We all in this Chamber want to stop climate change.But I can in no way understand how some in this House, especially in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health, can so completely turn a blind eye to the facts.Ifthe Environment Committeewillgothrougha woodedEuropeanMemberStates,whowill take carespecificallyof carbon sinks andclimate changeprevention,are being punished.I firmly believe that it makes enough sense in this House to vote in favor of the PPE amendment tabled by the rapporteur, Norbert Lins - whose work I really thank - in order to make sense of this.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened carefully to the debate today and I am encouraged by the engagement of the Members of this House. I appreciate your commitment to maintaining the European Union’s role as a path-breaker in the area of international climate action.  Following the debate I would like to clarify two issues. The first one relates to what Mr Brannen said. It is correct that the Commission proposal mentioned the term ‘intensity’. However it was never meant to be a static historical value. Forest management will have to flexibly adapt to the age—class structure of the forest and this means that the intensity will not necessarily stay constant over time but might change in a forward—looking forest reference level. The second one relays that the Commission is very much aware of the specific situation of the forest-richest Member States. They have a particular potential for a flourishing bio-economy and this can help in replacing emissions from many sectors, especially through harvested wood products and also biofuels, while at the same time maintaining, or even raising, the forest sinks. This is very much appreciated and will be acknowledged in the accounting system. Finally allow me to state that discussions on the two non-ETS proposals have progressed well in the Council and the technical work is nearly finalised. I would like to thank you for taking this important step in Parliament, which provides crucial political momentum for this proposal. I am convinced that the Council, under the leadership of the Estonian Presidency, will be able to move forward swiftly before the next climate conference in Bonn in November.  The European Union, as a driving force behind the High Ambition Coalition cannot come to Bonn empty-handed.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Thank you for the lively and controversial discussion we have had over the past hour. I would like to comment a little on a few requests to speak. On the one hand from colleague Brennan, but also from colleague Hautala. I believe that we are at least partially wrong if we - put simply - are of the opinion that less logging means more climate protection. This is definitely not what science has brought to me over the past few months. No, it's about a smart approach, it's about the question: When is the best time to cut wood? Because it is clear that a tree can absorb more and more CO2 for a long time, but then reaches a zenith and can then absorb less from this point in time. To put it a bit more pointedly: A national park, which is primarily created to ensure more biodiversity, is definitely not a forest that protects the climate, but on the contrary: In simplified terms, one can say that a national park is, in the long run, a climate polluter, because of course it can absorb less CO2 in the long run. And then bioeconomy: the Paris climate protection agreement also clearly states that we have to increase this. So that means we have to try to get more forest. It is also about the question: which age group? There are different situations in the Member States; the commissioner presented it. That means, if in doubt, I can significantly expand my logging, but still have a sink effect, even a higher sink effect in the long term, if I cut the right age group. In this respect, it would be right and good to support the EPP amendment in plenary on Wednesday and thus achieve a realistic approach. And then, when we have a majority here on Wednesday - which I would like - it will be the Council's turn. I am the Believes that he has to come to a result very quickly so that we can enter the debate, the trialogue, in order to improve the good Commission proposal in the end, so that in the end everyone can live with this compromise.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - Mr President, Dear Colleagues This legislative report proposes to put in place a framework for the consideration of greenhouse gas emissions and removals in the land use and forestry sector. It is one of the three pillars of the European Union's action framework for climate and energy up to 2030. It is a cornerstone of the European Union's action plan to achieve the objectives of the Paris Agreement. In the negotiations within the Parliament, I campaigned for the recognition of the active and sustainable management of forests, by giving the possibility to the actors of the wood sector to exploit the full potential of the forest resources, while ensuring the growth of carbon sinks in our forests. I consider that this proposal respects national competence in the matter and allows Member States to implement ambitious policies, adapted to local resources. For these reasons, I invite you to support this report. Thank you

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! The legislative proposal to address greenhouse gas emissions and removals related to land use, land use change and forestry in the 2030 framework for climate and energy policy is broadly in line with the European Council conclusions of 23-24 October 2014. The starting point is therefore in line with the policy framework set by the Heads of Government and State. On the road to achieving the Paris climate targets, it is very important that the LULUCF sector adheres to the so-called A “negative balance ban” to have only a neutral effect on the 2030 -40% emission reduction target in the worst case. However, at the level of detailed rules, I would like to draw attention to the provisions on the accounting of managed forest areas. The reference levels should be set in such a way that the base management period is as close as possible to the current data, reflects a country's forest management trends and does not limit the future forestry policies of that Member State. The European Commission should not be given the right to arbitrarily override the forest reference levels set by the Member State, but should also take into account the opinion of experts, as in the case of reviews. I believe that the compromise negotiated by my colleague, Norbert Lins, is closer to these ideas than the original Commission proposal, which is why I support his report.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: written. - European forests and good soil management are responsible for fixing more than 300M tons of CO2, almost 10% of the emissions produced by the EU. Land use will soon occupy a place in the climate policy of the Union and its States, which will have to comply with accounting rules to balance GHG emissions and removals. However, these standards do not account for emissions from biomass-generated energy. This reduces the weight of the absorptive and sink capacity of forests and soils, compared to their exploitation as biomass or wood, a factor that should not be excluded. The energy policies of some States include the use of biomass to achieve the objectives of renewables thanks to forests, causing two negative consequences: a) extracting biomass with more permissive levels can lead to loss of the forest fixation capacity of CO2, and b) all the Emissions from this burning are out of the count, that is, they contribute to warming without being accounted for. Europe cannot and must not deceive itself with an energy policy that downplays the importance that its forests and soils deserve as decisive actors in reducing the carbon emission.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the report by Sven Giegold on Transparency, Accountability and Integrity in European Institutions (2015/2041 (INI)) (A8-0133 / 2017).

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank all of my colleagues for their cooperation. In part it was a difficult birth, but in the end we had a strong majority in the AFCO committee for this report, and I hope that we will continue with that here in plenary. It is important to deal with the question of democracy in the European institutions. Democratic institutions need two things: strong participation and the ability to make decisions in the interests of the majority while respecting fundamental rights and freedoms. In more and more areas, democracy depends on the fact that we can only establish decision-making ability at European level internationally. The ability to make decisions is no longer just national when we see that more and more questions are ultimately global or at least continental. It is therefore crucial that we take the citizens with us on this path to more European and international democracy. And for this we also have to ask ourselves the question of participation, because only through both together - participation and the ability to act - can we achieve legitimation. Europe has already achieved great things in many areas in order to show that democracy with strong participation and transparency is possible internationally and not just nationally. We already show a lot, especially here in the European Parliament, but there is less about us in the newspaper. That is why our effective transparency and accountability are not yet optimally developed for many citizens. And we should aim to get the most out of what is possible in terms of transparency, accountability, and integrity. That is why our report makes some wishes to the Commission: We want the rules on lobby transparency not only to apply to the Commissioners and the highest officials, but for other employees. In the area of ​​trade policy, we want what was started with TTIP to finally apply effectively to all trade contracts, so that there is more transparency. In expert groups, the minutes should also present minority positions. We need a European legal framework for whistleblowers, and finally, when it comes to assessing conflicts of interest in the Commission, the Commission should no longer determine its own judges; instead, in the proposal for a new Code of Conduct, we need independent judges this question. And last but not least, we would like a proposal from the European Commission so that we have strong transparency and participation rights for all EU agencies and not just for a few, as is the case today. But when we make wishes to the Council and also to the Commission, then we should also look at ourselves critically. What does not work is, as unfortunately some colleagues would like us to demand strong lobby transparency from the Commission and the Council, but say to ourselves: everything here has to be based on voluntariness. On the contrary, we need full transparency here in Parliament, also in the eyes of the citizens. And that should ultimately at least apply to everyone who has a role here - that is, as rapporteurs, shadow rapporteurs or committee chairmen. They should show the citizens who they were talking to, as is normal in Canada. Why is that not possible in the European Parliament? The Commission has led the way; we as Parliament should follow suit. We have a good opportunity to make that clear when we vote on Thursday.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: – Madam President, this report has been a long time in the making, meaning that, as shadow, I have had very fruitful engagement with Mr Giegold, to whom I give my congratulations. It is an important report and, in a way, I think the time taken underlines this. Transparency is the central part of democracy, and this has to be the starting point. The problem is that there is a point where transparency comes into conflict with privacy and confidentiality, so any regulation of transparency has to establish an equilibrium between the two: between openness and confidentiality. At the same time, it must also pay heed to security and to those seeking to breach that security. I think the report achieves this. I am very much in favour of it. My thanks to Mr Giegold.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: - Madam President! The Social Democrats in this House are in favor of transparency in the representation of interests vis-à-vis the European institutions. We have worked very intensively on this report with the rapporteur Sven Giegold over the past few months - thanks for his commitment, he was persistent. There was a lot of resistance, as Mr Schöpflin has already said - but: What we will adopt on Thursday will bring some progress in the new openness in European policy, for the Commission, for this House and, hopefully, for the Council too, because the Council has so far been the There is a black box, and there really has to be a new agility there to open up more. The focus is on the transparency register, which we are now really bringing up again. We are better at this than many of the Member States, and very often we do not even exist. We are now saying: Nobody comes into our house if they have not registered, we recommend all Members not to meet anyone who is not registered. Finances and customers have to be disclosed, so an important step and an important stage, more will certainly follow.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, transparency and accountability are the foundations of democracy and should characterize the functioning of the European Union, and in particular the Commission. In addition, conflicts of interest should be explicitly prohibited, such as the possibility for companies of EU officials to apply for or subcontract EU funds. In addition, legislation is needed on the legal responsibilities of the members of the Commission, commensurate with the criminal responsibilities of the ministers of the Member States. Integrity and balance in the composition of expert teams should be put on the agenda and their CVs should be published. Full transparency and access to documents. Not this disgrace we had with TTIP. The role of the ombudsman is important, especially in relation to the issue of ‘revolving doors’, as Commission members cannot leave when they leave to work for private companies that were under their control. Transparency in both the ECB and the national central banks, in particular in relation to what they buy under the QE program.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: - Madam President! Many thanks in particular to Sven Giegold for this report, which is absolutely essential for greater transparency in the European institutions. I would like to agree with those who have specifically called on the Council of Ministers and the governments of the member states in particular to work to ensure that the arguments and the voting results and the documents relating to the voting are also put on the table in the Council's working groups, so that journalists are able to report on it. We are in a political union. We are no longer a diplomatic round of negotiations in which you first exchange arguments internally and at some point afterwards the public also hears about it. There must be opportunities to influence, and that is only possible if the Council discloses its documents and makes its negotiations public. Otherwise the Council has no place in the legislation of the European Union in the future either, but then it is only the European Parliament that should vote on these issues.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, it is a common secret that in the minds of the vast majority of the peoples of the European Union, both the leadership and the institutions of the Union have been discredited. Unfortunately, this position is justified, because many of the above have shown by their behavior that they are not only interested in the interests of the Union. They are only interested in themselves, in how they will be illegal, how they will be bribed, how they will create bank accounts in countries with tax havens and, in general, how they will serve their own interests and not the interests of the whole. This unacceptable situation must change, people must be selected and promoted who are distinguished for their knowledge, ethics and, above all, their willingness to contribute to the whole. If that does not happen, then we should not wonder why, in the eyes of its people, the European Union has become so devalued.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: - Madam President!The language is sometimes quite revealing.Note that you like to call those you do not agree with lobbyists, while you often call those you agree with important societal interests.The fact is, however, that everyone who tries to influence us is actually a lobbyist.It is good.It's called democracy.It is almost a human right to contact those who make decisions.Some of the most active, and in my opinion successful, lobbyists are our environmental organizations.That is why I think it is important that we do not make it difficult for people to contact us.Therefore, one should not introduce a lot of bureaucratic registers that make it more tricky, because it is we as members who are always responsible for everything we propose and everything we vote on.If you are afraid that even MEPs will be deceived by lobbyists, then I have a clear recommendation: Choose better MEPs!

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, it is excellent to see this comprehensive report on transparency and accountability in the EU institutions. If we expect to represent our constituents properly in a democratic EU, we need to make sure our constituents can see what we are doing and know that we have their best interests at heart. When former Commissioner Barroso announced his job with a big bank last year, I joined many colleagues to call for the Commission’s rules on conflicts of interest to be tightened, and I am glad to see that demand being made once again in this report. That should accompany greater transparency in this House, too, including an effective mandatory transparency register. There is more work to do, but at least we can demonstrate that we will keep on pushing forwards for more ethical politics.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I agree that the European Union has done a great deal for transparency, for the heart of democracy, as my colleague said. At that one minute, I do not just want to talk about the positive thing that the European Union has done, but about what awaits us. The rapporteur uses the term 'effective responsibility'. I very much agree with him. I think that it is at the level of lobbying that we should regulate lobbying contacts in the lower floors, because the highest floors are perhaps already quite lit. But on the lower floors, it looks like if it's not dark, there's at least fog. I think it is appropriate to change this, as the report suggests. With regard to conflicts of interest, we are witnessing major scandals that are really affecting the reputation of the European Union, which is taking us to the depths of politics, and it would be good if the European Commission also took the lead, especially when appointing judges, for example. I think that is one of the burning issues.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank the rapporteur, Mr Giegold, and the rapporteurs of the five committees who have given an opinion on this file for this important and wide-ranging report.  The Juncker Commission has committed to lead by example when it comes to transparency. At the very beginning of our mandate, the College committed to high transparency standards. This lies at the heart of the Democratic Change priority in the Political Guidelines for this Commission. Being transparent about the way European institutions work, including how they interact with interest representatives, is essential to ensuring public trust. The Report recognises that the Commission is a very transparent public administration. Let me give you four examples of recent improvements. Firstly, as far as transparency of interest representation is concerned, since December 2014, Commissioners, Members of their Cabinet and Directors—General have been publishing information on their websites on the meetings they have with lobbyists. Information on more than 14 000 meetings has been published to date. The rule ‘not on the Transparency Register, no meeting’ applies as well. These were simple but major and unprecedented steps forward, which illustrate the high standards that we apply. Secondly, we have made registration in the Transparency Register a requirement in order for stakeholder organisations and individual experts representing a common interest to be appointed as members of expert groups advising the Commission. Thirdly, we have boosted transparency in trade negotiations. This is essential to ensure the legitimacy of European Union trade policy and public trust, as the report rightly recognises. Fourthly, the Commission’s Better Regulation policy also contains a series of important new transparency features with open public consultations and other opportunities for feedback at each stage of the policy cycle. For the first time, the public can provide feedback on draft delegated and implementing acts. So the Commission has led by example in terms of transparency, and we believe it is now time for other institutions to make a similar effort so that we can together strengthen the transparency of European Union law—making, which is a shared responsibility of the Parliament, Council and Commission.  This is why the Commission has presented a proposal for a mandatory European Union Transparency Register, in the form of a draft interinstitutional agreement covering the Parliament, the Commission and, for the first time, the Council. We welcome the adoption of Parliament’s negotiating mandate in June. A first tripartite political meeting took place on 6 September 2017, and we look forward to the start of the formal negotiations. The objective is to have the highest standards in place in the three institutions for their interactions with interest representatives. The Commission is of the view that meetings of interest representatives – including meetings with MEPs – should be made conditional on these interest representatives being in the Transparency Register. If all three institutions adopt the ‘not registered, no meeting’ approach, which the Commission already applies, registration will become a precondition for exercising lobbying activities vis-à-vis EU institutions. This is why an interinstitutional agreement is the most pragmatic and efficient way to achieving a mandatory Register. It would be a major step forward towards the transparency that citizens rightly expect. I would also like to share some first observations about other key points raised in the report. Regarding ethics, the Commission’s Code of Good Administrative Behaviour for staff in their relations with the public reflects the values of service, independence, responsibility, accountability, efficiency and transparency, to which the Commission as an institution is committed. The Commission strongly supports the objective of protecting whistleblowers, underlined by the European Parliament. The results of the recent public consultation and a study will enable the Commission to take an informed decision on the need for further horizontal or sectorial action at EU level. As far as the work of agencies in providing scientific advice for policymaking is concerned, the Commission supports their approach to effectively preventing conflicts of interest, while maintaining their ability to access the best available expertise. Finally, I would like to reassure you that the Commission will examine carefully all the proposals for legislative and non-legislative initiatives put forward by Parliament in this report and will express its opinion in the formal follow-up procedure following the adoption of the report. We look forward to continued good cooperation between our institutions, so that, together, we can reinforce further the transparency and integrity framework of the European institutions.
