name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. - The adoption of this report is crucial to ensure a strong European Parliament mandate for negotiations with the Commission and the Member States on the EU Transparency Register for lobbyists. It is essential that the European Commission's ethics committee, which analyzes violations of the code of conduct, is chosen and can decide independently, and that the period of disgust between the end of the mandate and the acceptance of jobs in the private sector is extended. We also argue that all relevant Commission staff should only meet with entities registered in the Transparency Register and that these meetings be published. I also hope that Parliament will approve the amendments proposed this week by the rapporteur, which concern the mandatory publication by rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs of all meetings with interest representatives and the determination of a period of disgust that lasts while the payment of the temporary transition allowance, with any decision on positions taken in the private sector after the mandate being evaluated by an independent authority. It is the least we can do to meet citizens' ethical and integrity requirements.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: On the agenda is the report by Constanze Krehl on a space strategy for Europe (2016/2325 (INI)) (A8-0250 / 2017).

name: Constanze KREHL
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! I would like to thank the Commission for the proposal for a new space strategy and the shadow rapporteurs for the really excellent cooperation on this not unimportant subject. There is unbelievable potential for all of us in space, which must be used wisely. Space is not far away, but now affects our daily life. A current example for those who do not yet know: Copernicus data is currently being used for the hurricane disaster in the Caribbean and Florida in order to be able to provide better help on site. But there are also many other areas of application, such as climate change, monitoring CO2 or methane emissions, agriculture, fishing, large construction projects - for example, the bridge between Denmark and Sweden was supported, among other things, with data from European satellites so that the both ends of the bridge actually meet. Modern traffic systems are supported, including the navigation system - for which we are currently still dependent on the United States - but also connectivity, the development of remote regions for a high-performance Internet, and even coping with the refugee crisis: all of this can or can be better managed can only be realized with support from space. This requires a clever strategy of what and how to invest in which areas. The Commission's proposals are on the table. We discussed our report in Parliament and further refined and expanded the proposals. We need broad application of data from space in the European Union. We also need to promote it - both in society and in the economy. Communication about this has to be improved as well as the corresponding training, because for many it is still completely unknown what possibilities the space projects of the European Union offer us at all. The existing projects must be continued and expanded. We must make better use of the opportunities that Galileo, EGNOS and Copernicus offer, not only in the social sphere, but also in the economic sphere. In traffic management on water, on land and in the air, data from space could be used to a much greater extent, but it is also possible to use this data economically in the development of new applications in the field of startups and in small and medium-sized companies . The SMEs must be supported accordingly, and if necessary we must also take legislative action. Local authorities should also be encouraged and supported more strongly to take advantage of the EU's space activities - for example in urban development, transport planning or civil protection. The EIB could finance such projects, but the Structural Funds could also play a bigger role. In these tasks, it must be ensured on the one hand that our space factor is globally competitive and that it is treated fairly on the market, which affects, among other things, the financial resources of our programs. In the future, too, we need a European budget for the space policy that cannot be reduced - on the contrary: satellites only have a limited lifespan and public investments are currently much higher, for example in the USA. However, efficient, pragmatic cooperation between the EU, ESA and the member states and the efficient use of European programs, such as the Horizon research program, are also important. The space programs are civil programs, but there can be useful synergies, for example with the European action plan for defense and in the fight against terrorism. Of course there is also security important for the systems in space.Increasing space debris, an increasing number of large and small satellites, but also cyberattacks can cause great damage.We have to be more active here.For a peaceful use of space we need a strong EU and good international ties.The cooperation between the Commission, the Council, the European External Action Service and ESA is therefore of great importance.Parliament will accompany this and asks the Commission to provide a concrete roadmap for the individual program parts and to develop a communication strategy.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I also welcome the European Commission's proposal in the space development strategy.At the same time, I want to say that the agency that deals with this development is based in Prague.I think that the technologies we use, which have their source or origin in the universe where they operate, so their use is really everyday, affect our lives, as the rapporteur very rightly said.I like the way in which the report raises the issue of start-ups.And not only start-ups, but also small and medium-sized enterprises and the use of these technologies by these recipients.I would very much like to appreciate that the rapporteur has emphasized the role of municipalities and cities and regions in planning their development and using these technologies, which have their source in space.I think this is a very innovative approach and I would like to thank her for it.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the report that we will approve tomorrow contributes to the elaboration of a space strategy for Europe, a strategic sector of fundamental importance, although often ignored by public opinion. In reality, the space sector does not represent a cost for citizens, but an investment: space programs and related services are fundamental resources for many economic sectors such as energy, environment, defense, health, agriculture, transport, the digital market, mobile communications and many more. To respond to current and future challenges, the next multiannual financial framework should include an adequate envelope for the space sector. It is essential to ensure the continuity of programs and to reflect on the future evolution of Galileo and Copernicus, in particular in order to create a positive climate for investment in the sector. However, particular attention should be paid to the vulnerability of space infrastructures to interference or attacks. It is important to ensure the security of critical infrastructures and media, as well as to develop resilient technologies.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, space today cannot be treated simply as another market for private investors. That would be irresponsible. Decisions on space directly affect countries' security, but may also have long-term consequences for the natural environment. So space cannot become a market like all the others. Space technologies have added value for many sectors, such as telecommunications and transportation. Thus, the European Union must stop treating space with the same ideologies as it does the other areas of joint action. First of all, space politics involves research, that is, human resource development. Finally, the European Union must work in the field of space not only with the United States and Japan but also with other space powers, such as China, India and Russia, in order to maximize results in cutting-edge space technology and also , to put all this in the service of humanity.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, back in 1967, the United Nations was the sponsor of the International Space Treaty, which pointed out that it is practically becoming the domain of all mankind. In the meantime, a lot has changed, technologies have gone far ahead and, of course, everything said in the report has my full support, especially programs like Galileo, Copernicus and of course I advocate, also, to anticipate new funds, because everything that the universe provides, all the resources it has, just to mention satellite tracking, really helps our life on our planet. However, I would go a step further. And I want to warn you that the US Federal Aviation Administration has announced that it will encourage the private sector to pursue commercial activities and in the form of obtaining exclusive rights to parts of the territory on the Moon. Likewise, China has ambitions, in a way, to go to the moon. That is why, in 2015, I asked the Commission a question to which I did not receive a satisfactory answer: what will it do to protect the interests of the European Union on the Moon as well?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, space has ceased to be an unknown space that creates fear and awe in man. It has now been approached, researched and utilized in order to offer benefits to society. Space affects our daily lives, provides access to technological advances, feeds us information through the satellites installed on it, and, in general, could create jobs if used properly. Above all, however, space also affects politics, and for this very reason, a careful strategic plan must be made for its constructive use by the European Union in cooperation with other countries that have the potential to develop technology, to take advantage of this design and generally promote the dimension of success and perspective on issues related to its relationship with the world.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Ms Krehl for her excellent report and support. Last October the Commission adopted the Space Strategy for Europe. It is the first comprehensive strategy in this sector at European level. We sent a clear signal: space is a priority for the Commission, and the Strategy represents a clear ambition to make Europe a leading actor in space. We are therefore glad that the report to be adopted supports this level of ambition and goes even further in some respects. The report fully endorses the vision of the Commission and puts on the table several very concrete and constructive suggestions in relation to the four priority objectives of the Strategy: maximising the benefits of space for society and the economy, and the creation of a European market for space-based applications; fostering a competitive and innovative European space sector and a new space approach in Europe; ensuring Europe’s autonomous and secure access to space; and strengthening Europe as a global actor. The implementation of the Strategy has already started and is already delivering benefits. All our space programmes are operational. The latest Copernicus Sentinel 2B satellite was successfully launched and the data is already being used, for instance, to direct rescue teams during the recent earthquakes in Italy or the follow-up to hurricane Harvey in Texas. Galileo’s initial services went live last December. The market uptake is the key to success. Leading chipset companies are producing Galileo-compatible products and, at present, already 13 models of smartphones can work with Galileo signals. EGNOS has also demonstrated its added value: today, 424 procedures for aircraft approach and landing have been developed at 288 European airports, allowing passengers to easily access regional airports. The European Union Space Surveillance and Tracking, or SST, support framework started in July 2016 to monitor debris in space to protect European critical space and ground infrastructure, paving the way towards less dependence in this domain. This is a good start, but we cannot stop there. This year, and the next two, will be crucial. We are committed to implement the actions announced in the Space Strategy, and our intention is to use the same inclusive process as the one we used for the preparation of the Strategy. Our priorities are clear. First, on the market uptake, several actions have started to foster space-based applications in relation to Copernicus and Galileo. Second, we need to boost space start-ups, for instance through discussions with the European Investment Bank. The Commission is ready to look at different options to increase the efficiency of space research spending, including by exploring the options of possible public-private partnerships. Third, we need to prepare the continued evolution of Copernicus and Galileo. This starts by an evaluation of what has been done so far. Fourth, the synergies between the security and the defence dimension need to be reinforced, for instance through the link with the European Defence Fund. The work on the GovSatCom initiative and on the reinforcement of the SST will take this dimension into account. Fifth, the autonomous access to space needs to be guaranteed, and we are working on a smart strategy for launchers. Finally, we do not forget the governance aspects and the need to cooperate closely between all European actors, in particular with the European Space Agency. We take this very seriously. These priorities will be likely reflected in legislative proposals in the coming years. But the future will also depend on the budgetary aspects. Adequate financing and resources are necessary to meet the current and future challenges. As the report rightly outlines, space applications serve many European policies and actions: space is not a cost but an investment. Let us work together to ensure that Europe benefits from a true return on this investment. Let us work together towards achieving a strong Europe in space – a domain where no single European actor can succeed alone. Europe is at its best when it is ambitious.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The point is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, September 12, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing. - This is the first European space strategy, so this is an important moment for the future of Europe and for several reasons. Guaranteeing independent European access to space is essential if we want a stronger and freer Europe on the international stage. Space is in all public policies, starting with environmental issues, defense, agriculture, digital ... it is a transversal sector! Our industry, and in particular our SMEs, must have the means to achieve our ambitions, so we must support them so that they can develop their activities, produce in Europe and have long-term visibility, in particular for European launchers. In particular, we must offer SMEs the possibility of making better use of spatial data to develop services and concrete applications. This will require an ambitious budget for research, for infrastructure and for space programs, Galileo and Copernicus in particular. Finally, we urgently need to train young Europeans in the specific skills required by the space sector. Many jobs will be created in the future!

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - Between 2014 and 2020, the EU will invest over € 12 billion in space activities. These funds are well spent as Europe is developing world-class space systems such as the Copernikus satellite program for earth observation, and EGNOS and Galileo for satellite navigation and geopositioning. There are currently 18 satellites from European space programs in orbit, and this number is expected to increase to 30 over the next 15 years. The European space economy, including manufacturing and services, employs over 230,000 professionals and in 2014 achieved a value added of 54 billion euros, which corresponds to 21% of the global sector. The technologies, data and services provided by the European space sector are already indispensable in our daily lives. Space has become part of the global value chain. Products and services such as Velcro, solar cells, improved weather forecasts, navigation programs, etc. have been developed around the world and made available to the general public. Another reason for the need to strengthen the European space economy is to guarantee Europe's strategic autonomy in the future. By strengthening the European space economy, key and high technology will also be strengthened. High-tech sectors must be kept in Europe and further developed; they help to maintain the competitiveness of Europe as a location.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the report by Maria Arena on the impact of international trade and EU trade policies on global value chains (2016/2301 (INI) (A8-0269 / 2017).

name: Maria ARENA
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, our globalized economic system is based on fragmented and mass production processes. Most of the goods we consume today are the result of a combination of various operations from all corners of the world. Sometimes for the best: complementary research, innovation partnerships, resources and raw materials that must be sought in a respectful manner. Sometimes for the worse: cheap labor, unprotected, environmental destruction, tax evasion. These operations are often coordinated by international companies through contractual partnerships or multiple subcontracting. The European Union, as the world's leading exporter and importer of goods and services can - and I would even say must - use its trade policy as a real lever to make these global value chains tools for development. sustainable for all and thus contribute to a fairer and more equitable globalization. Currently, the lack of transparency and the dilution of responsibilities throughout this process increase the risks of exploitation of workers, the non-respect of fundamental rights and promote unfair competition on a social level, on an environmental level, but also on a fiscal level. This report also takes place in a context where European trade policy is the subject of strong criticism from citizens who demand a fairer and more transparent globalization. He therefore calls on the Commission to take a whole series of measures to make global value chains more accountable and transparent. To name but a few, I will target, for example, the inclusion in trade agreements of a binding but also enforceable "sustainable development" chapter, as well as the anti-avoidance clause. tax and tax evasion. There is also the taking of initiatives inspired by the legislation on conflict minerals or the company's duty of vigilance within a binding duty of vigilance framework as set out by the OECD, or the establishment of a labeling system that guarantees a production method that respects international labor standards and / or environmental standards. I will cite, for example, the initiative taken by Italy today regarding the labeling of the origin of tomatoes produced in a respectful manner. Many other important elements can also be found in this report such as the initiatives and the role of the private sector, multilateralism and end-of-life support. This report is the result of long negotiations between the different visions of how to master this globalization. We have found, it seems to me, a good balance in the search for a common goal, which is to make trade a tool for emancipation for all. One of our colleagues recently quoted the wise words of Simone Veil, who said: "The search for compromises must lead us towards a solution higher than the particular position of each one". This report, in my opinion, illustrates that research. I thank the shadow rapporteurs, especially Mr Ruas, here present, for having indeed found the compromises which could satisfy us all. I hope that many of us will vote for this report tomorrow.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I listened very carefully to what the rapporteur had to say and I think, by and large, it was a very balanced and sensible contribution. As a Member of the INTA Committee, I take a huge interest in trade, and trade is very important, because if you produce a good, you must sell it, and obviously, if you are the European Union, being able to make trade deals around the world has had a huge positive impact overall on the economy in all our Member States. The Korean agreement is probably the best, being hugely successful, growing exports by almost 50 per cent in the space of four years. But where there are problems, as the rapporteur pointed out, they must be looked at and dealt with in package with all the other issues.  So I think the solution is to go ahead and have our trade agreements, but look at the downside and consult with the stakeholders to ensure that any negative aspects are minimised.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the trade policy of the Union, particularly on the international side, has recently become a major concern for public opinion. Treatments like CETA are not the correct way to set up a trade policy. The protests and reactions that have been seen throughout Europe show first of all that SMEs are the central element of the global value chain: free trade treaties, if not properly modulated, bury small European producers, putting them in competition with companies. that do not meet the same quality standards and save on raw materials and labor. The European Union, in setting its political and trade agenda, must remain faithful to certain indispensable principles, responding effectively to social and environmental dumping, combating unfair commercial practices and ensuring the dignity and rights of workers, but to at the same time it must remember to protect its specificities and its excellence. We cannot continue to sell them off as soon as possible.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the Free Trade Agreements have essentially dismantled the economies of developed countries and at the same time opened up markets where the exploitation of peoples for a piece of bread by the multinationals has prevailed. And this is clear and understandable. So it is time to take action. We must therefore have significant pressure on the countries where the multinational products are produced, in order, first of all, to comply with labor law, to have acceded to the conventions of the International Labor Organization. Secondly, there must be a clause on the protection of human rights. In addition, there must be a clause for compliance with environmental conditions. We should not allow child labor and exploitation and forced labor. I think these are necessary elements in order to be able to have a different perception of international trade.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Arena, on this great report because, let's face it, only the European Union has the moral strength to establish a value chain on our planet. None other than the European Union. And that is, I think, a very important message that we must send to this debate and to the vote tomorrow. I want to highlight three key points as I see them, and that is really exploitation in many countries of workers, cheap labor, too cheap labor, I want to highlight the problem of tax evasion, tax havens and everything else we know about taxes, the problem of environmental protection and environmental destruction in general in some states. In the end, we usually pay for all this again, because the European Union is the largest donor and helps the most various developing countries, other countries with which we have trade agreements. In this context, I think this is one very comprehensive report, and I would like to thank my colleague Arena once again for it.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first thank the European Parliament, the Committee on International Trade (INTA) and the rapporteur, Ms Maria Arena, for the attention, work and time that they have invested in this report. The Commission shares with the European Parliament concerns and goals regarding sustainable development and the 2030 Agenda, both of which are central to many European Union policies, including the trade and investment policy. The European Union policy on corporate social responsibility and responsible business conduct is implemented through initiatives by businesses and by their stakeholders, complemented where necessary by adequate regulatory measures. I would like to recall that corporate social responsibility is mostly a voluntary process, and enterprises are responsible for the impact they have on society. Let me just briefly recall some of the many actions we take in the area of global value chains. As regards European Union trade and investment policy, recent European Union trade agreements contain rules of origin that support the integration of the industry in the global value chains. In all trade negotiations, the Commission is promoting provisions on public procurement and intellectual property rights. In this context, we aim at developing solid procurement tools against corruptive practices and promoting sustainable procurement. These agreements also contain provisions on corporate social responsibility and responsible business conduct, together with binding commitments on core labour standards and international environmental conventions which are subject to dispute settlement. We also work with the OECD in developing due diligence guidelines and on their implementation. Under the unilateral Generalised Scheme of Preferences, corporate social responsibility is indirectly addressed via the requirements and dialogues on labour standards and environmental conventions.  And as regards the gender dimension, the Commission is developing further its trade-related policies. Following the Gender Forum hosted by the Commission earlier this year, more will be done on promoting gender equality and integration into bilateral and multilateral instruments, such as the trade negotiations with Chile or the WTO Ministerial Conference in December 2017. Also, as regards other policies, the Commission takes numerous actions linked to global value chains: there are capacity—building and outreach programmes which help developing countries to promote reforms for effective enforcement of social, environmental and labour standards. Support is given to European Union small and micro enterprises, taking on board the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. The Commission cooperates closely with the International Labour Organization on decent working conditions in global supply chains, but also on occupational safety and health, social dialogue, child labour and forced labour in supply chains. With regard to jurisdiction rules, work is done within the Hague Conference on Private International Law, and we are negotiating a worldwide convention on recognition and enforcement of judgments by indirect jurisdiction rules with third states. The European Union also has legislation in place for corporate social responsibility and responsible business conduct. Let me give you just two examples. The 2014 Non-Financial Disclosure Directive for large European Union companies requires companies with more than 500 employees to disclose information on policies, results and risks concerning environmental aspects, social and labour-related matters, respect for human rights, anti—corruption and bribery issues. And the 2015 Anti-Money Laundering Directive puts in place rules that reinforce the vigilance by banks, lawyers, accountants and other professionals as regards, among other things, the identification of beneficial owners of companies and trusts.  We are addressing all these sustainable development issues – and many more – on a regular basis, and the Commission will continue to work closely with the European Parliament on them.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item on the agenda is the Milan Zver report on continuing and distance university education in the framework of the European lifelong learning strategy (2016/2142 (INI)) (A8-0252 / 2017).

name: Milan ZVER
text: Rapporteur. - In July, the Culture Committee adopted a report entitled Academic further and distance education as part of the European lifelong learning strategy with 24 votes in favor and only one against. I would like to highlight the fruitful cooperation with almost all political groups. Obviously, education connects, especially when it comes to topics as good as the two I bring together in the report. It is not particularly emphasized that education and training is a mirror of society. It contributes not only to the maturation of individuals, but also to the formation of human capital and society in general. Education has been high on the European agenda for many years, although it is widely known to be part of the sovereign policies of its members. The European Union has been promoting the quality and efficiency of school systems in the Member States for many years. Therefore, it has prepared a series of mechanisms that make education more comparable and of better quality, as well as a series of programs that financially support education and training. Let me pay special attention to the success story, which we call Erasmus +, but we will talk about it in this plenary. The concept of lifelong learning is based on the realization that in a modern dynamic, complex and technologically increasingly demanding society, full of risks, it is necessary to have lifelong education, be it formal, informal or casual. In the report, I emphasize the need for further academic education in the field of vocational education and training. All those who have successfully completed school must have access to additional educational pathways on which participants can further fulfill their abilities. Colleagues, poor access to educational opportunities can lead to less competitive people in the labor market, problems in private life, permanent passivity, exclusion from the social environment and, as can be seen in recent years, violent radicalization, especially of young people they are vulnerable in risky circumstances. Access to education is therefore a standard that must be enforced everywhere, but this is not the case in practice. Many have this kind of problem, e.g. young mothers find it difficult to reconcile their family, perhaps even work, responsibilities with educational ones. People from the lower classes find it difficult to afford the desired study, especially if it is too expensive. Someone from the peripheral regions also finds it difficult to afford to study at desired university destinations that are not close enough. Even for individuals who are classified in the group of people with special needs, participation in the classic t. i. residential mode of study is often impossible. That is why distance learning is so important in providing easier access for all, which is one of the most important goals of education and training in general. In short, distance learning can improve accessibility for all, without discrimination based on country, region, social status, age or gender. Distance learning also significantly reduces costs for the provider and the participant. Thus, distance learning also enables greater personalization of studies, as it is less uniform and more adapted to the needs and potentials of the student. In doing so, we are helping to increase efficiency and reduce early school leaving, which is still a major problem in Europe. The process of digitization is also unstoppable in education, especially in distance learning. In this context, the assistance of the European Union in the development of a single and friendly digital platform is also very important. digital classrooms. Today, there are open universities in the world that bring together such digital classrooms of hundreds of thousands of participants from dozens of countries around the world. In the Union, too, we should adopt more quickly the good practices that are already established in the world. And one last sentence. In fact, this report speaks to the future of education in two important respects: if we want a knowledge-based economy and, consequently, a knowledge-based society, school systems in the Member States must urgently open up to new challenges.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for presenting the report and also for the very detailed and well-founded justification here in plenary.As he said, distance and further education is simply an opportunity that we do not use enough yet.This report recalls the very rapid changes in the labor market, in fact, from 2025 onwards, we can assume that almost half of all jobs in the European Union will need higher education, almost forty percent will require secondary education and only eleven percent will be low or unskilled..It is therefore a matter of developing human capital, which we should support in this way.It is also an opportunity for university development.At European Union level, we are proposing better sharing of experience and greater comparability of qualifications, greater flexibility in these programs, as well as teacher training and development.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as a result of the digital transformation, education systems are facing significant challenges, and continuing and distance academic training makes a significant contribution to training. This type of training must become an integral part of the European strategy for lifelong learning; in fact it represents a possible approach in the context of continuing academic education, which can help to ensure a balance between study, professional life and private life. According to recent estimates, barely a quarter of pupils in Europe have teachers with adequate familiarity with digital tools. It is clear that any strategy in this area must first of all deal with this digital divide. However, the qualitative aspect of teaching should not be overshadowed: the need to guarantee high standards in distance learning and the importance of developing new teaching and learning models must be considered part of the process of innovation and gradual digitization of education.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, education and training are very important factors for social and economic change itself. At the same time, they support the development process itself. In fact, lifelong learning, combined with distance training, are important tools to equip women with skills and thus have the opportunity to return to employment itself and improve their capabilities in the work process. In fact, distance education is also important for people with disabilities, who are not easy to move around. At the same time, the educational process, which is tailored to the needs of the students themselves, helps to address the phenomenon of school dropout. In addition, there should be procedures in place to support the skills of the trainers themselves and, finally, we should find a system that contributes to the recognition of professional qualifications at European Union level.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, today technologies enable us almost everything, especially when we talk about digital technologies, by creating digital platforms, which is very well recognized in this report by Mr. Zver, who goes on to point out everything that is important for lifelong learning and learning ondistance.In particular, I must support the fact of recognizing people with personal needs.What I would like to point out in another way is precisely the need to connect European universities.We have very interesting, good connectivity programs, but I think they are still insufficient.I will point out a good example of connecting universities in the Adriatic known as ADRION, where universities cooperate with each other, exchange programs, professors and students, but I think that by creating concrete digital platforms between different universities, we can achieve even greater quality.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Madam President, digitization represents an unstoppable process in society. As is evident, this reality represents a crucial challenge with university education and professional training. In this sense, however, it is important to underline that, despite these advances, a significant part of the population does not yet have access to these technologies. It is also important to mention that there are still economic barriers that condition access to technology, or promote differentiated access among citizens. But, above all, we want to underline here that, despite being favorable to technological advances in general and to digital in particular, we must create a model that places these advances at the service of humanity and not at the service of a few oligopolies. Unfortunately, reality shows that the digitization of the economy has fueled precarious work. The digitization of education can help, but it cannot replace the presence of the teacher, nor can it fuel mass dismissals and further exploitation, and above all, it cannot replace the role of the State in guaranteeing equal access for all citizens to university education. .

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: - Madam President, I welcome the report of my colleague Zver and believe that it provides all the key facts that should encourage both the Commission and the Member States to successfully implement the new modernized education system, lifelong learning system and distance education.The global competitiveness of the European Union will not only be measured in how successfully our industry will be digitized, our transport will be digitized, energy will be digitized, but how successfully the education system will be digitized.Not only should it be at the university level, it should be at the professional level, it should help ensure that education is present in our remote mountainous regions, islands, where people often do not have the opportunity to travel to the mainland and participate in their lifelong learningimportant for their retraining and finding a position in the labor market.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think my colleague Mr Zver, the rapporteur, ticked all the boxes in relation to this very important topic. Indeed, I remember when I came here first as an MEP in 2009, I was struck by the emphasis, in the Committee on Culture and Education in particular, on lifelong learning. It is a concept that is well established now and recognised by almost everybody: you just have to keep on learning to keep up to speed. You could be an expert today, but should you not keep up to speed on what is happening in your chosen area, you could be out of date tomorrow. I think that distance learning and technological improvements, etc., are a major challenge, not just to individuals, but also to third-level institutions, to be able to provide the expertise that is needed to keep up with what is happening in the world. I also think it is very important that emphasis is put on people with disabilities and people from the lower socio-economic areas. Everybody is entitled to education, and everybody is entitled to have lifelong learning.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for giving me the opportunity to comment on this draft resolution, which is very much in line with the Commission’s own policy and strategy.  On 30 May, we published an education package, which contains actions spanning from early childhood education and care to higher education, and which includes a strong focus on both digital and lifelong learning. The package takes account of developments and issues that have a direct impact on education – such as globalisation, digitalisation, diversity and exclusion – and considers how best to support people of all ages in developing the skills that they will need to thrive both personally and professionally. Many of the actions are very relevant to the recommendations in the draft resolution. The Commission Communication on ‘School development and excellent teaching for a great start in life’ starts from the assumption that high-quality education for all will help Europe achieve its economic and social objectives while fostering the personal and professional developments of European citizens.  I would like to thank you for highlighting the importance of Erasmus+ and Horizon 2020 for enhancing lifelong learning, and for the call to bridge technological gaps between educational institutions across Europe and to connect schools to ultra-fast Internet, thus addressing the digital divide and ensuring equal opportunities for all students.  I would also like to thank you for your acknowledgment in your report of the work done through the eTwinning and School Education Gateway platforms. In order to improve learning outcomes, inclusiveness and equity in school education, the Commission plans to further promote participation in those online platforms. Further actions planned of particular relevance include a digital capacity self-assessment tool based on the Digital Competence Framework and called ‘Selfie’, which enables schools in the European Union, on a voluntary basis, to self-evaluate where they stand in relation to common criteria on the effective use of technologies for digital age learning, and how they can further improve. In addition, through Erasmus+, we will support improvements in school-level education in science, technologies, engineering and maths by promoting best practice in developing links and cooperation between higher education, research, businesses and schools at European Union level. I would also like to highlight three initiatives within our renewed European Union agenda for higher education that are relevant to your draft resolution.  We will develop and implement a digital readiness model to help higher education institutions, their staff and students to implement digital learning strategies and exploit the potential of technology. We will provide support through Erasmus+ for higher education teachers, doctoral candidates and postdoctoral graduates to develop pedagogical and curriculum design skills, including in digital learning. Also through Erasmus+, we will promote the development and testing of flexible and modular course design. Let me also mention the Commission’s support for research and innovation projects under Horizon 2020, developing ICT applications for education and training, making learning more effective, engaging and collaborative. We are also conscious of the importance of youth work in supporting young people from disadvantaged backgrounds in developing digital skills and competences. The Commission welcomes, therefore, the reference to recognising competences gained outside the formal education system. Last but not least, we should emphasise the important role of Erasmus+ and Horizon 2020 in supporting innovation in all sectors of education, and for people of all ages.  For the next three years (2018-2020) Erasmus+ will implement the ‘Digital Opportunity Scheme’, supporting internships to develop digital skills. Through our Horizon 2020 stakeholders, as well as through the Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition, we have been mobilising companies to offer more internships in this field, strengthening Europe’s innovation capacity.  One of the EU’s most successful programmes, Erasmus+ contributes to promoting growth and jobs, developing skills and promoting European values and social cohesion. Over the last 30 years, it has had an impact on the personal and professional lives of more than nine million participants, within and outside Europe. Among others, it funds eTwinning, promoting cooperation between schools through distance learning. There are clear and strong messages at the highest political level regarding the crucial role of Erasmus+ in supporting the goals of the Rome Declaration, specifically ‘a Union where young people receive the best education and training and can study and find jobs across the continent’.  The recommendations within this draft resolution will provide us with much inspiration in our continued work to provide the best possible support to people of all ages on their lifelong learning journey.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The point is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, September 12, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - This report was an opportunity to get everyone to agree. Who can deny the need to further enable distance learning using digital technology? No one. But as too often, the theme of the proposal has been kidnapped to serve ideological ends. Why introduce gender issues? Why so many measures with regard to refugees when we are waiting for real proposals for the majority of the population? Why so much dictate their educational policies to States when this falls within their competence? Is it so hard to carry out a fair analysis of the general situation and to propose solutions for all? What good is it for my roofer to tell me what my front door should be like? What right can he ask that I change my interior? Obviously, it is impossible for some to set out in search of the common good. While they should be working to find solutions for the citizens, they are spending all their energy in the struggle for their personal struggles. This is how they create new problems instead of solving them. They advance their pawns while the citizens wait.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I want to thank the rapporteur for this own-initiative report. The topic of e-learning is very important in Europe. It gives a lot of opportunities to people, regardless of their age, sex or social status. Easier access to education should be the standard universally applied, but in practice that is not the case, unfortunately. For example, it is hard for poorer people to obtain access to education. Working mothers might face difficulties juggling their family responsibilities, work and education. Furthermore, people with specific needs finds it hard to participate in traditional education. That is why I see e-learning as an optimal solution which can make access to education much better and more efficient, as well as reduce the social gap between different classes of societies in Member States. I believe that e-learning will become the new traditional form of education due to digitalisation of all spheres of our lives.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: in writing. – I would like to thank Mr Zver for his work on this report. Lifelong learning is not only a mandatory part of every human life, but it is highly integrated into our traditional educational system. Since it is imperative by today’s standards to hone ones knowledge, experience and skills, the educational system has to acknowledge rapid changes in circumstances and adapt accordingly. Poor access to education can be a cause for uncompetitive workforces, social exclusion and even violent radicalisation. With the help of e-learning and distance education, even people who cannot access classical education because of insufficient funds, disabilities or other hindering factors are not being excluded from the learning process. Increasing unemployment rate in Europe could be held in check and dropout rates from schools may shrink if these new methods of education were properly implemented and access to them was ensured. Further and distance education framework in Europe should be built upon a cooperation of the Member states also in the area of digital skills. More teachers need to be acquainted with digital competences and an EU-wide online platform to exchange good practices should be created.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for one-minute interventions on important political issues (Rule 163).

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Madam President, on 1 September, the Association Agreement between Ukraine and the European Union entered into force in full. Article 4 includes the protection of civil and minority rights, non-discrimination. However, with the Education Law adopted on 5 September, Ukraine violated these principles and obligations, as Article 7 of it abolishes the right of Hungarians, Romanians, Bulgarians, Poles and Slovaks in Ukraine to study in their mother tongue at all levels of the education system. The law thus contradicts Ukraine's constitution and international obligations. It undermines relations with neighboring countries that support it, calls into question the sincerity of Europe's integration efforts. This legislation will have serious consequences for national minorities living in Ukraine, with tens of thousands of children, parents and teachers becoming disenfranchised, second-class citizens. I call on the leaders of the European Commission and the European Parliament to exercise their influence so that the President does not sign the law in this form and refers back to the recast of Article 7, as this will close 120 Romanian, 100 Hungarian and 5 Polish-language schools. to occur.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: - Dear colleagues, this week, among other extremely important topics, we are also discussing the future of the Erasmus + program and the new Agenda for Skills in Europe. It is a good framework to reaffirm in the European Parliament our support for education that gives young people a real chance for a successful professional life. I believe, along with many other MEPs and many citizens, that in the global economy, Europe's only competitive advantage will come as a result of a focus and massive investment in education in all its forms. A successful professional life depends, in many cases, on training courses, apprenticeship and internship programs through which young Europeans can learn, train and increase their chances of employment or training. I would like to emphasize, however, that not all young people have the necessary resources and that, for many of them, an internship, a paid internship, is the only chance to support themselves. I want us all to think in this week's debates about how our vote and the positions we have taken can make a decisive difference in the lives of many young Europeans who, with just a little bit of support and backing, can have a chance to reach its true potential.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Madam President!When discussing important social issues, I would like to ask especially those who care so much about the rule of law in Poland: where is the Dutch and Belgian rule of law that made it possible to poison Europe with fipronil, which was used especially in Dutch, Belgian and German chicken farms.The incident, named by the representative of the European Commission, has been going on for a year, as the Belgian Food Safety Agency has documents that indicate the presence of fipronil in Dutch eggs at the end of November 2016, and the first samples were taken in May this year.The information was not received by the Member States until July 2017, which meant that millions of eggs and contaminated chicken meat were delivered to the markets or consumed or used in the production of ready meals, posing a threat to public health and the environment.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, UNESCO World Heritage is endangered in many places.Only in the area where I live, where I live, where I move in Croatia, in Plitvice, in Dubrovnik, in Venice, in Ohrid, in Kotor, in some other parts, the UNESCO heritage is endangered for nothing but us, due to tourism.Tourism that is very important to us, tourism in which every tenth citizen of the European Union works, tourism that brings in large incomes, but also tourism that we almost never talk about here in this European Parliament.As if it does not exist, as if it does not bring income to Europe and as if in this case it does not endanger the UNESCO heritage.So, once again, I want to make a clear commitment here that we need an umbrella tourism organization within the European Union, so that we can really deal with tourism in a quality way when we talk about cultural heritage.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to talk to you about a young man of 32 years old. He is Franco-Palestinian, he lives in Jerusalem and he has just become a lawyer. A few days after graduating as a lawyer, he was arrested on August 23 at his home without reason and, after much procrastination by the Israeli justice system, he is placed, like millions of Palestinians, in administrative detention - it seems. on the basis of a secret file because it is totally empty. His name is Salah Hamouri. This reveals the relentlessness and total lack of respect for the law by a state that constantly proclaims itself one of our closest partners. Our external action service cannot let this happen and must demand the release of Salah Hamouri unconditionally and without delay. It is high time that the European Union made its cooperation with the State of Israel conditional on respect for fundamental rights, law and international conventions, as it does with so many other States. Immediate freedom for Salah Hamouri.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this evening I brought an exceptional product to the Chamber: tomato sauce. This is a product that comes from southern Italy, but the same could be said for Greece, for Spain, for all those countries that have a lot of sun. It is a healthy product and is a fundamental ingredient for foods such as pasta, pizza, lasagna, and is therefore a real wealth of our territories and our local productions: we do not call it "red gold". Yet we wonder how it is possible that the European Union is unable to prevent, block imports of Chinese concentrate, which is a poor and low-quality product, which competes unfairly with our production and, above all, which is harmful. because it is full of pesticides. We wonder how it is possible that there is no precise and clear label to distinguish the Italian tomato from the Chinese Xinjiang, so that citizens can freely and consciously choose what to eat.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is incredible that parliamentarians must defend the products and dignity of European citizens and their culture. In the United States, animated by the worst historical revisionism, the shameful campaign is underway against two very important figures of our tradition, very dear to Italians, Europeans and in particular Italian Americans. The first targeted, just think, nothing less than the figure of Christopher Columbus: it is asked to eliminate any reference to this character, to demolish statues, etc. The second concerns another character, also important, an Italian aviation hero, great flyer, Italio Balbo, who is another important historical figure. I ask that, in the face of the grave silence of the High Representative, who never defends Europeans, European values ​​and the dignity of European citizens, even threatened, outraged as in this case, the European Parliament provide, and I extend an urgent invitation to the President to make his voices heard in defense of Cristoforo Colombo and Italo Balbo.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - At the moment, the European Union is dealing with the situation in Poland because it says that it cares about democracy and the rule of law.Well, you can't have both.Either there is democracy or there is the rule of law.There is no compromise here.If the constitution requires that an "A" be done, and the people and parliament demand that "B" be done, then the officer has to know whether to do "A", and then there is the rule of law, whether to do "B", and then there isdemocration.You cannot have both.At present, in Poland we are dealing with an attack by democracy on the rule of law.Most have the majority and change the law as they wish.This is what democracy is.I am an enemy of democracy, I hate democracy, but I want law to rule.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, tonight I would like to talk about forest fires and point out the need for protection against forest fires. The worst fire season is behind us. There were 4907 fires in Croatia this year. However, they not only affected Croatia but also Spain, Portugal, Italy and Greece. In any case, I asked seven questions during this term of office to the European Commission to point out better protection of European forests from fire. Climate change and global warming should not be overlooked either. While we here in Europe have been fighting fires, we have the biggest hurricanes and tornadoes in Central America, which in a way indicates changes in the global climate. What I want to say with this presentation today is that the Solidarity Fund that exists, unfortunately, can be mobilized very slowly. What we are asking from the Commission is to enable a faster mobilization of the Solidarity Fund, which is currently serving to help with these natural disasters. I ask you, in that sense, to react.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Madam President, it is not the first time that crimes against humanity have taken place against the Rohingya community. This Parliament has previously passed two resolutions on Myanmar last year, and yet the brutality and even atrocities continue against the Rohingya Muslims. How many more women will be raped? How many more children will be tortured? How many more villages will be burnt? What will it take for this genocide and ethnic cleansing to be stopped? The resolution on Thursday needs to go further than any previous resolution, including economic and political sanctions against the Myanmar government. The international community needs to move faster. We need urgent action and impact now. We will need to recognise the Rohingya Muslims and support humanitarian efforts – not just now, immediately, but in the long term. This institution – the EU – is based on the values of peace and cooperation. It is only right that we show solidarity and play our part in bringing peace, justice and prosperity in Burma.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman! After a series of attacks on Poland against the background of the differences between the executive and the judiciary - and it must be said that the tensions between these authorities are embedded in the very logic of the separation of powers - the time has come that is completely unexpected for us: Poland is under attack because it wants to guarantee women the right to early retirement rest. Well, I want to make the European Commission aware, I have already told Vice-President Timmermans about it, that on July 15, 2010, the Polish Constitutional Court clearly stated that the right of women to early retirement rest is part of the constitutional rights of women resulting from motherhood, resulting from childbearing, often resulting from helping children in the older period of life. Of course, other countries may adopt other constitutional solutions, but we cannot speak of defending the Tribunal and the constitutional order in Poland, while attacking its principles defined precisely by the Constitutional Tribunal, and for this constitutional order we demand respect.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, Bosnia and Herzegovina has the lowest financial support per capita from the EU, not only among the Balkan candidate countries but also among the accession countries. This is not consistent with EU ambitions to strive for international cooperation and support these Balkan countries ravaged by the war, socialism, and nationalism, especially since Bosnia and Herzegovina’s constitution – the Dayton Agreement, mainly the result of western pressure – does not allow the country to progress. Therefore I welcome the Commissioner’s answer to my question: that he is considering increasing the financial support to Bosnia through the Instrument for Pre—Accession. This will enable the country to take the necessary action crucial for Bosnia’s integration into the European Union and further development. I think the country should also be compensated for the lack of support in previous times.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Madam President, Portugal is facing an unprecedented drought that requires urgent support. The latest data provided by the Portuguese Institute of the Sea and the Atmosphere state that, at the end of June, 80% of mainland Portugal was in severe or extreme drought. In addition, 18 of the 60 mainland dams started a summer with less than half the water they can store. According to the drought meteorological index, on July 30, the situation of meteorological drought was maintained in almost the entire territory of mainland Portugal, with the intensity of its intensity worsening in relation to the previous month. In addition to the fires, the damage caused by the drastic decrease in crop productivity and the lack of water and hardware for farm animals is already starting to be estimated at several hundred million euros in various sectors of agriculture and farming. In this very serious situation, we affirm that the advance payments of CAP aid to farmers are not enough. It is necessary to go further by activating the European Union's solidarity fund, adapting its regulation so that it can help now, in order to minimize an impending catastrophe, which will be social, economic and environmental.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Madam President, the European Union has lost the confidence of the people. The left, right and center parties that support her see the 2019 European elections arriving with anguish. This is why they are imagining an electoral system that could skew the results in their favor. Their idea - supported by Emmanuel Macron - is to create, alongside national lists, transnational lists which would be voted on by all Europeans. French candidates in difficulty in their country could thus be elected by voters from other European states. This is a real lifeline for the Greens, who have almost disappeared from the French political scene. It was enough to think about it: since the French people vote badly, the Eurocracy changes the people. The subterfuge is scandalous. Shamefully, the Union is once again trying to circumvent the results of universal suffrage as it did to destroy the French referendum of 2005. But the ENL group will oppose it.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: - Madam President, all national minorities have the right to education in their mother tongue, from kindergarten to university, in any country in Europe, within the Union or in its neighborhood.This fundamental right also belongs to the Hungarian and Romanian communities in Ukraine.Ukraine's new education law is anti-minority and contrary to European values.As a Member of the European Parliament of the Hungarian Democratic Union in Romania, I consider the decision of the Ukrainian Parliament to be flawed and I express my solidarity with the Hungarian community in Transcarpathia and the Romanian community in Ukraine.Solidarity is natural, especially when Hungarians in Romania are also threatened with legal aggression.The Hungarians had to take to the streets in Târgu Mureş, just a few days before the start of the school year, in order for a Hungarian school to continue operating.I call on the Ukrainian head of state not to promulgate the law on education, to refer it back to parliament for renegotiation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for 48 hours Italy has been hit by violent storms which have caused enormous damage and unfortunately victims, as in Livorno. The adverse weather wave also hit the southern regions last night, especially Campania, with the provinces of Naples, Caserta and Salerno. Italy has never been plagued by such devastating storms with the frequency of recent years, in which climate change is showing its effects. The difficult situation of hydrogeological instability must be urgently addressed and the absolute need for investments in terms of prevention and safety is evident. Public interventions are needed and Europe's help is also needed if we do not want these emergencies to continue to repeat themselves in a cyclical way. In these hours the possibility of requesting the recognition of the state of natural disaster is being evaluated, verifying the accessibility to the European Solidarity Fund and to other measures for which Europe, if called upon, I am sure will not lack its support.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, today marks the anniversary of the death of Chilean President Salvador Allende on September 11, 1973, after a fascist coup. A dictatorship of terror was established in Chile for almost twenty years, opening a long period of application of policies against workers and the labor movement. Allende, like many others, died defending a system for the people, a system in which the person prevails over capital, in which lives are more important than multinationals and the market. Forty-four years after that death, his legacy takes on stronger than ever: in the face of the systematic loss of rights and freedoms, from the left we continue to fight for truly democratic institutions; so that workers are the center of policies; for eradicating inequality; to advance, in short, towards socialism. Today as yesterday, as Allende said, "history is ours and the peoples make it.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: - Madam President! In a few days, the great Zapad military maneuvers organized by the Russian Federation will take place on the territory of Belarus. According to reports, these maneuvers will involve over one hundred thousand soldiers, several hundred tanks, artillery and air force. These are the greatest maneuvers since the collapse of the Soviet Union. The gathering of such large forces at the eastern border of the European Union must cause great concern, as it directly threatens the security of the European Union. I believe that the European Union should express its firm opposition to this behavior by the Russian Federation. I would like to point out that also in a few days, on September 17, we will mark the 78th anniversary of the treacherous barbaric attack by the Soviet Union on Poland in 1938. The organization of military maneuvers on these days is a provocation. I appeal to the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission to respond appropriately to these behaviors of the Russian Federation.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, when I was elected in 2014, I decided to be a voice for people who did not have a voice. This Parliament offers a powerful platform and we should be mindful to draw attention to ethnic minorities and indigenous people, whose rights are trampled over by voracious global interests or who are marginalised by poor public policy and a lack of investment.  Whether it is the Xikrin people of Amazonia whom I visited last month, whose lives are unsustainable because of mineral extraction, deforestation, land grabs and political corruption, or the Roma population of Europe who were victims of the Nazi Holocaust and who continue to suffer terrible discrimination, we should remember them in our political discourse, cherish their cultural distinctiveness and speak out against those who abuse them. When we do so, we can be a force for good. I am glad therefore that ahead of Roma Pride on 1 October, the Czech Government has announced they will end the scandal of the pig farm Lety on the site of a Roma genocide. Meanwhile, the Xikrin have won an important injunction to halt the Onca Puma Mining Project and will receive full compensation for its poisonous effects. We can do good.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, on 10 March 2016, Tony Taylor, a Republican from my home town of Derry, was detained and interned on the instructions of the then British Secretary of State for the North, Theresa Villiers. Today, over a year later, no evidence has been produced to justify his detention, nor indeed his arrest. If evidence exists, it should be presented to the courts. His continued detention is a breach of human rights and an affront to justice. This is why Sinn Féin has been calling for his immediate release from Maghaberry Prison and why I, along with the newly elected MP for the North, Elisha McCallion, will visit Tony Taylor on Friday. The refusal to release him raises serious concerns about political interference in the criminal justice system in the North. Internment was wrong in the 1970s and it is still wrong.  This is Tony Taylor.  (The speaker held up a photograph of Mr Taylor). He should be immediately released.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, the school year has begun in Romania today, but in a city half inhabited by Romanians and Hungarians, this has been preceded by more chaos than usual. This is due to the fact that the fate of the local Hungarian school founded by the Roman Catholic Church was slowly uncertain a year ago, the institution built in the church's own building virtually ceased due to serial harassment by various state authorities, . I talked about it here months ago, but please imagine the situation where, due to an administrative error a few years ago, dreaded anti-corruption prosecutors are investigating on the spot, summoning parents for questioning why they enrolled their children in a Catholic school. Yes, this is happening in the Union, not somewhere in the Third World. If we are talking about the rule of law, we need to be aware that parents in Târgu Mureş feel so much about legal certainty in the European Union today.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: - I am glad that the alarm signals raised by me in this plenary regarding the tragic situation of one of the oldest and most experienced vaccine production institutes in Europe, namely the Ioan Cantacuzino Institute in Bucharest, had a prompt and positive response from part of the current Government of Romania. The Prime Minister of Romania, Mr. Mihai Tudose, announced the other day the preparation of the legislative documents necessary for the transition of the Ioan Cantacuzino Institute from the Ministry of Health to the Ministry of Defense, starting from the idea that the Cantacuzino Institute is part of the strategic network. a widespread epidemic or a biological weapon attack. According to the Prime Minister of Romania, there is an intention for the Ioan Cantacuzino Institute to become the main European regional center for vaccine production, so necessary for the immunization programs of European citizens. I go further and ask for your support in finding an acceptable formula for the European Commission, through which the financing of the endowments and operation of the Ioan Cantacuzino Institute, but also of similar institutions in other Member States, will be made from the European budget.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, on August 23, the Brazilian Government published a decree that foresaw the extinction of the National Reserve of Cobre e Associados, a territory in the Amazon with about 4 million hectares that encompasses nine protected areas among state forests, ecological reserves and indigenous lands, which immediately gave rise to the massacre of isolated Indians in the Amazon due to the prospecting of gold and the slaughter of birds, as reported by the National Indian Foundation (Funai). The subsequent suspension of this decree by a federal judge is merely provisional and the Government's second decree, which revoked the first, only opens more loopholes for exploitation in some of these locations. Dear Colleagues, in a moment of great dynamism in the negotiations between the European Union and Mercosur - which may lead to a political agreement before the end of this year - the European Union cannot fail to urge the Brazilian authorities to preserve the indigenous environmental reserves of a of the largest continuous strips of tropical forest on the planet. Brazilian Indians and the Amazon, also known as the “lung of the world”, cannot continue to be constantly threatened by economic interests.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: .The darkest Stalin era is reminiscent of the recently voted amendment to the Ukrainian Education Law, which would deprive minorities, including Hungarians and Romanians, of the fundamental right to learn in their mother tongue.Both the Hungarian and Romanian governments are sharply protesting against this.The illegal and discriminatory abolition of the Hungarian-language Roman Catholic grammar school in Târgu Mureş evokes the spirit and methods of the assimilation policy of the national communist Ceausescu dictatorship.Romania cannot apply a double standard to domestic and Ukrainian minority education!I ask Parliament and the President-in-Office to intervene to ensure language rights in Ukraine and to resolve the situation in the Romanian school.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I have asked to be able to take the floor to express my gratitude to the presidency of this House, first of all, and to the rest of the colleagues who this afternoon, at the beginning of the work of this plenary session, They have observed a minute of silence, not only respectful, but also emotional for the victims of natural disasters or terrorist attacks that have occurred in recent weeks. Attacking Barcelona, ​​the city where I live and where I was born, or attacking Cambrils or attacking Turku is basically the same thing: an attack on our civilization, our way of life, our democracies, our rights and our freedoms. I end by reminding myself again of all the victims of these attacks and of all the others that unfortunately have occurred on European soil and beyond, as well as reiterating the gratitude for the work carried out by the security and emergency forces and bodies, especially the Cos de Mossos d'Esquadra, who with such diligence and know-how worked during those dramatic hours of August 17. Do not have for!

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, in the summer, the Italian authorities showed that some non-profit organizations were cooperating with smugglers and traveling directly to Libyan shores for economic migrants.There, they even allowed smugglers to take engines from the ships they used to bring migrants, take them back and bring others.I would like to take this opportunity to call on the European Commission not to be lax in helping the Italian Government to mobilize forces and take action against these groups and, if so, if these groups or non-profit organizations do not comply with the code by which the Italian Government called on them to work together.stopped all funding and refused to cooperate in rescue operations.I think that the people who are moved to Italy do not make the most of this whole business, smugglers make money from it.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I read with great interest the recent position papers on Brexit that were released by the United Kingdom Government and, indeed, I followed the latest round of negotiations closely. Allow me to state the obvious, which is that something is evidently missing: solutions. One area in particular, in which solutions are needed quickly, is the Ireland-Northern Ireland border. The referendum was 15 months ago but I have yet to read anything really concrete on the border issue. What is the holdup? Does the United Kingdom take its citizens in Northern Ireland seriously? The time for buzzwords is over. I have lost count of how many times I have read in the position papers buzzwords like ‘streamlined’, ‘innovative’, and ‘imaginative solutions’ for the borders of the United Kingdom, but without any details of what these solutions would look like. This is bureaucratic speak for ‘we haven’t a clue’. The onus is on the United Kingdom to come up with something substantive and workable, that does not put a hard border back on the island of Ireland. The United Kingdom made a decision to leave; now it must solve the problem it has caused for Ireland.
